title: Swedens WAGS stay hotel ENGLAND team
story: Swedish WAGs like Maja Nilsen (pictured) wife of Man Utd's Victor Lindelof are staying at the Renaissance with the England teamEngland's players will be staying in the same hotel as the Swedish WAGs ahead of tomorrow's World Cup quarter final, MailOnline can reveal.Harry Kane and his teammates will sleep in the 196-room Renaissance in Samara where Sweden's wives and girlfriends will also be staying.But the Swedes are bragging they already have the edge after they were booked into Samara's only five-star resort - leaving England in a more modest four-star hotel. Sweden's FA President Karl-Erik Nilsson joked: 'You could say Sweden is one-zero up already.'  His countrymen are in the Lotte Hotel, which opened in April, and is the best hotel in the area.   The hotel's sumptuous  fine food menu lists the amount of calories contained in each item for weight watchers - which even has its own caviar menu where a spoonful of Stugeon is available for £71 and a lesser 'Pike' variety for £16.Their players can also tuck into tuna with chukka seaweed salad, crab cake with tomato salsa, roast duck, creme of pumpkin soup with Kamchatka crab and cream cheese and tiger shrimp and scallop brochettes and a filet Mignion steak.          Harry Kane and his teammates will sleep in the 196-room Renaissance (pictured) in Samara where Sweden's wives and girlfriends will also be staying          England has been allocated the four-star Renaissance (foyer pictured) Hotel in Samara while their World Cup quarter final opponents are staying at the town's only five star resort           Sweden are crowing to have been allocated better accommodation than their rivals. Their FA President Karl-Erik Nilsson (left) joked: 'You could say Sweden is one-zero up already.'Rebekah Vardy reveals the England sex ban has been lifted...Share this articleThe country's FA general secretary Hakan Sjostrand chuckled: 'Yes we also have caviar on the menu, but that will be OK as long as England have their fish and chips.' Meanwhile Gareth Southgate's men will be staying on the outskirts next door to an Ibis hotel with a McDonalds nearby and traffic streaming outside and fridge magnets are on sale in the foyer for  £1.50. The Renaissance offers a range of salads, soups, grilled meat and fish in its 'Terrace' restaurant with its most pricey item being a grilled steak for £22.           England boss Gareth Southgate had no say in the hotel, which was chosen by FIFAHowever, England's players rarely eat in hotel restaurants and have their own food prepared for them by an official FA chef.The 196-room Renaissance was opened in 2003 with rates starting at £70 a night compared to the more expensive Lotte where the cheapest rooms are £200. But the standard of cotton sheets and the fine food will be forgotten once the teams do battle for a place in the World Cup semi-finals.Mr Nilsson, who was wearing his country's football short and is a Wolverhampton Wanderers fan, said: ' FIFA chose this hotel. So it is one-zero for us then.'We do have caviar, but I am pretty sure they can manage without caviar and it will be a good game. Otherwise they are welcome to visit us. It will be a fantastic match between two great teams.'He added: 'We had Netherlands and France in our (qualifying) group and we beat Italy in a play off. We beat Portugal last year in a friendly.          The Swedes are in the Lotte Hotel (pictured), which opened in April, and is the best hotel in the area where the cheapest rooms available at the moment are £200 per night          The Lotte's sumptuous fine food on offer even has its own caviar menu where a spoonful of Stugeon is available for £71 and a lesser 'Pike' variety for £16'And we won the group of four here which had Germany in it and we have just beaten Switzerland in Russia who are ranked sixth in the world…why shouldn't we be confident?'We also have the biggest respect for our opponents. But we go in to the quarter final in a very good mood.'  The Swedish delegation have been privately meeting human and civil rights leaders in Russia and supporting their work. Mr Sjostrand added: ' England have so many good players and they should beat us. But it would be so boring if life was always like that.'He said the Swedish fans would support England if Sweden is knocked out and added: 'Harry Kane is a fantastic player and we follow the Premier League in Sweden.    Despite Sweden claiming victory in the battle of the hotels, Gareth Southgate's men will be hoping for a repeat of their heroics when they beat Colombia on Tuesday (pictured)'I am a Manchester United supporter and one of my daughters is called Ester because of Manchester.' I also follow Ashley Young , Rashford and Lingard. England have so many good players.He said he expected between 1000 and1500 fans to be in the Samara Arena on Saturday evening to be supporting Sweden.He added 'To come here is a challenge because of a lack of flights and it is really expensive.'We had 500-6000 people at our last match because it was in St Petersburg and it not so difficult to travel from Sweden. People came by car and by train through Finland.'We hope for a great match and of course a Swedish victory. But overall, a fair match which will be great for the supporters and enjoyed by the world.'

title: How Jesse Lingard Englands King Social Media
story: This tweet by Jesse Lingard this week assured his place as the king of social media in the England team, whose image has been transformed by players' use of Instagram and Twitter          He is now turning his footballing and online prowess into a strong brand, based on his distinctive goal celebration, in which he spells out his initials with his hands          He is now busy building a brand around his celebration and his nickname 'JLingz'The public's love of the England team is a million miles from when Sam Allardyce lost his job as England manager  after he was filmed talking to undercover reporters posing as businessmen.Back then, confidence in the national team was at rock bottom.  But now, just two years on, England have rebuilt their public image, thanks to squeaky-clean Gareth Southgate and his squad of fresh-faced young players.Among them is 25-year-old Lingard, who, with four million Instagram followers, is at the head of a group of stars whose social media posts are watched by thousands of young fans.EXCLUSIVE: Sweden's WAGS will stay at the same hotel as the...EXCLUSIVE: Man dumped by Gareth Southgate's wife for England...Share this articleA social media hit this week came Jesse filmed fellow young player Trent Alexander-Arnold saying 'It's coming home' to him on the pitch after the Colombia victory.Lingard has also posted videos of himself dancing in his pants with Ruben Loftus-Cheek in the changing room, being shaved by teammates and celebrating with fans.Such videos give fans a players' eye view of the World Cup and take supporters inside the England camp in a way never seen before.     He is currently believed to be single after his relationship with Jena Frumes ended in scandal          Jena split from Jesse before tweeting: 'At least I can say I tried plus enjoyed the ride'          Lingard and Ms Frumes split up in March after she posed for steamy pictures in his shirtSocial media experts say his and other players' tweets and videos are building a new image for the national side, totally distinct from the days of 'dentist chair' drinkathons and Graham Taylor's 'turnips'.Former Twitter head of sport Lewis Wiltshire told The Daily Star: 'If there is a player who uses Instagram better or more effectively than Jesse Lingard, I'm yet to see them.'These players are from a generation where they understand and enjoy this stuff.'I'm convinced it's at the heart of why this England team's public image is different from, say, 10 years ago.'Mr Wiltshire says he doesn't believe a representative handles Jesse's social media for him, as with other players, which may be part of its success.The Manchester United midfielder could now use his performances in the World Cup to launch a strong Beckham-like 'brand'.He has used Instagram to give fans a players-eye view of the World Cup, including video of him dancing in his pants in the changing room  He stays close to his grandmother and grandfather, who helped get him into football as a childThree weeks before the tournament, Lingard applied for four trademarks, three centred on his nickname 'JLingz' and another featuring his goal celebration, in which he holds his hands in front of his face and spells out his initials.He has since launched a clothing range, including caps, T-shirts and hoodies emblazoned with his goal celebration logo, which have already all sold out on his website jlingz.com.Andy Sutherden, head of sport  marketing at H+K Strategies, told CityAM: 'Jesse Lingard's team has acknowledged the fact that if he does well in Russia, there’s an immediate opportunity but one with a very short shelf life. 'They’re also understanding of the fact that people who become known for something different - think Crouch and the robot - extend their marketing appeal beyond the audience of sport.' Meanwhile, there are rumours that Manchester United bosses are set to increase his wages from £75,000 to £150,000 to keep other clubs from trying to tempt him away.          The 25-year-old midfielder is one of a new generation of players who is savvy with social media          While communicating with his millions of Instagram followers, he has created a strong brand          He has now used the platform to launch a range of clothing, including these JLingz capsOne thing that makes his social media postings different from some of teammates is the lack of a girlfriend.He dated childhood sweetheart Emma Hyde for five years until he ended it in 2016.He later went out with glamorous US-based Instagram model Jena Frumes, but she dumped him after a tabloid newspaper revealed he had sex with an admin assistant from Sheffield in a hot tub.Jesse remains committed to his family, and even has a picture of his mother Kirsty, 49, in his room in Russia.As a boy he attended Beamont Community Primary school in Warrington, where most of the boys his age wanted to play rugby league.His grandfather Ken, a former GB power lifter, was the one who suggested he take up football and ferried him to training sessions and matches.    Before the World Cup, he made his nickname and goal celebration logo trademarks          Lingard's recently-released clothing range has already completely sold out on his websiteWorld Cup 2018: England's Jesse Lingard has trademarked his JLingz celebration — and he's done so at the perfect time | City A.M.

title: Single shoe remains poacher eaten lions hunted rhinos
story: No leftovers: A single chewed-up shoe remains on the ground where three poachers were eaten by a pride of lions at the Sibuya Game Reserve  in Eastern Province, South AfricaThere are fears that they might have developed a taste for human flesh, having successfully hunted down and eaten the poachers.However, owner Nick Fox has sought to assure any worried potential visitors, saying they have not noticed any changes in the pride's behaviour around humans and will continue to monitor them.Karachi's cruel cages: African lions are ravaged by fungal...Never too young to kill: Trophy hunter CHILDREN pose...EXCLUSIVE: 'Men don't get the grief!' Hunter who posted...Share this article'Although we will continue to be extremely vigilant we remain positive that this incident will not necessitate any changes to the status quo,' he said.  The general consensus in the game industry is that lions view a game viewing vehicle containing people as something entirely different from iniduals who are walking on the ground. 'At Sibuya Game Reserve we only view game from specialised game viewing vehicles and not on foot due to the extremely dense bush and thick forest on the Reserve.'          Protecting the lands: Roxy the anti-poacher guard dog with her handler as they patrol the park          Dinner in sight: Lions at the Sibuya Game Reserve which would have been among those that devoured three rhino poachers this weekOne head and a number of bloodied body parts and limbs have been recovered from the area, along with three pairs of empty shoes. Staff at Sibuya also found high powered hunting rifles with silencers, wire cutters and an axe used by poachers to cut off rhino horns.A helicopter was called in to search for more possible poachers, but none have so far been found.Mr Fox, 60, said: 'We found enough body parts and three pairs of empty shoes which suggest to us that the lions ate at least three of them but it is thick bush and there could be more.'They came heavily armed with hunting rifles and axes which we have recovered and enough food to last them for several days so we suspect they were after all of our rhinos here.'But the lions are our watchers and guardians and they picked the wrong pride and became a meal.          Gruesome:  Staff found a head, along with a number of bloodied body parts and limbs at the scene along with three pairs of empty shoes          Nature's justice: At least three poachers are believed to have been eaten by lions at the Sibuya Game Reserve. Pictured: A lion at the Sibuya Game Reserve          Illegal hunt: The poachers had brought high powered hunting rifles with silencers, wire cutters and an axe known to be used by poachers to cut off rhino horns          At least three hunters are believed to have been devoured by the reserve's lion pride, pictured, judging by the bloody scene on the Sibuya Game Reserve'Whilst we are saddened at any loss of life the poachers came here to kill our animals and this sends out a very clear message to any other poachers that you will not always be the winner'.The game reserve is one of the most popular in the Eastern Cape, and it is visited by many British tourists.As well as rhinos and lions, Sibuya's 30 square miles is also is home to the rest of Africa's Big Five: elephant, buffalo and leopard.In 2016, the reserve lost three rhinos when poachers got into the park and shot them dead and cut off their horns.However, this time the hunters became the hunted, when they got in the way of the resident lion pride. Mr Fox said: 'The lions may have eaten more of them it is difficult to tell as the area is very thick with bush and you cannot be sure what they have taken off to feed on elsewhere.'The best estimate we have so far is that three of the gang were eaten.'They were armed with high powered rifles with silencers, an axe for the horns, wire cutters and side arms, so were clearly intent on killing rhinos and cutting off their horns.'    Poachers not welcome: A helicopter has searched the area, as more poachers may remain in hiding on the reserveThe remains of the bodies were found as darkness fell on July 3rd, but staff had to wait until daylight on July 4th when the area could be declared safe to go in and recover what was leftPolice spokeswoman Captain Mali Govender confirmed that the remains had been found in the lion camp and that detectives were on the scene trying to work out how many were eaten.Captain Govender said: 'We do not know identities but firearms have been taken by the police and will be sent to the ballistics laboratory to see if they have been used in poaching before'.Poaching is a major issue on the Eastern Cape with nine rhinos killed by illegal hunters on reserves this year. In February a poacher was killed by lions in the Umbabat Game Reserve near the Kruger National Park, and his family were forced to identify him using all that was left - his head.

title: Shocking moment gulper catfish swallows fish big itself
story: He is fin-ished! This picture appears to show the two fish as tank mates getting on well, but nothing could be further than that truth          Fishing for dinner: The black catfish latches on to its prey after circling it in the aquarium  The predator thrashes around the tank as it slowly devours the gold fish in one pieceIt never stood a chance in the underwater battle which took place in an aquarium in Indonesia. The 50-second video, which has been posted online, shows the gulper catfish briefly circling its prey before it extends its mouth and latches on to the head of the other fish. The gold fish thrashes around in the water as it tries to free itself from the catfish's jaws.But it is not enough to shake off the predator, which slowly devours its prey - inch by inch. Incredible slow-motion video shows the moment a brave er...In the drink! 18,000 barrels of liquor is destroyed as...Share this articleThere it goes! Despite the gold fish's efforts, it is unable to swim away from the catfish and is eaten whole          The other fish didn't stand a chance against the gulper which pounced without warningEven while feeding, the catfish carries on swimming - and swallowing - until the very last scale has been eaten. By the end of the video the catfish has almost doubled in size after expanding its highly-stretchable stomach to make room for its extra-large meal.The predatory fish, which has been known to readily consume strips of white fish, whole shrimp, earthworms  and even pigeons is a strict carnivore by nature. The gulper catfish is usually found in Brazil and Venezuela, where it inhabits blackwater tributaries. It tends to hunt in shallow water and is known to be typically active at night time.  The catfish gulps down its prey and quickly consumes the entire body of the other fish          Full: By the end of the video, the catfish has grown to twice its size as its stomach stretched with its food

title: Lost Turner masterpiece fetch 230 000 f
story: An unsigned painting by JMW Turner discovered in Scotland is believed to be worth six figures          Kirsty Archer-Thompson confirmed that the unsigned painting is a genuine turnerShe has confidently declared it to be an original by JMW Turner, one of the most celebrated British artists of all time.The watercolour is now on exhibition at Abbotsford, Sir Walter Scott's home in the Scottish Borders from 1812 to his death in 1832.Turner, who lived and worked in London, was known to have visited Abbotsford in 1831 as a guest of Scott and the painting is believed to be one of his early watercolour works of this view of Abbotsford.What do you do with a drunken seagull? Birds are left...STEAM trains! London tube passengers suffer in unbearable...Share this articleThey believe it could have been painted between 1831-1833. Kirsty Archer-Thompson, collection and interpretation manager, at Abbotsford is the Scott expert, who confirmed the painting as a Turner.She said: 'I'm willing to stick my neck on the line that it is a genuine Turner. We believe it to be one of his earlier watercolours.'          Libby Sheldon, pictured, agrees the painting is a genuine TurnerMs Archer-Thompson revealed that cross-border cooperation had resulted in the lost Turner coming to light.She said: 'The private collector of the lost Turner watercolour is English.We met him through a Scottish connection, who is another art collector.''I first saw the painting in March at the collector's private residence.'He bought the painting a few years ago but has been researching it because he wanted to find out more as he thought there was something special about it.'I knew it was a genuine Turner. I was completely moved when I held it in my hands. It is something to hold it in your hand rather than behind a glass, which is great about my job. This is probably the highlight of my career.'The private collector paid peanuts for it - a two-figure sum - only for a national gem to be discovered.'Extensive archival research was undertaken to build up a case for why this was a genuine Turner painting from his life and time at Abbotsford.Her role was using her expert knowledge in the subject to help the owner unravel the story behind the painting of Scott's home. Combining that with the scientific study of the painting has enabled Ms Archer-Thompson to make the case.Ms Archer-Thompson is convinced it is a Turner because a pencil sketch, which can only be seen by infra-red imaging reveals the artist's original sketch. This has been adapated and changed siginficantly in the paint.The type of paper used for the watercolour also matches Turner's use of materials but the main focus was on the date of the frame and the paint.The scene of the Tuner painting is also found in the engraved commemorative book after Scott's death.Ms Archer-Thompson added: 'Not very long ago another lost Turner watercolour appeared and was sold for £230,000.'The tiny watercolour, which is poket sized, measures at 5.5 inches by 3.5 inches.Libby Sheldon, a painting analyst expert, 'supports the theory' the Turner is a genuine.Ms Archer-Thompson, added: 'All of this analysis, including work by painting expert Libby Sheldon, demonstrates that it was executed by an astonishingly skilled hand.'          The painting is believed to have been painted at the Scottish home of Sir Walter Scott, picturedWhen Turner stayed at Scott's house in August 1831, the writer showed the renowned painter his art collection, amongst which is believed to be a view of Abbotsford and the River Tweed by Scottish artist Elizabeth Nasmyth.Ms Archer-Thompson said: 'This painting is from exactly the same vantage point we believe Turner painted.'Scott had a personal attachment to the Nasmyth painting and its composition and my theory is that this gave Turner the idea to compose the same scene, which he based on sketches in the Abbotsford sketchbook used during his visit in 1831.'Abbotsford House Trust chairman James Holloway, a former director of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery in Edinburgh, added: 'It is wonderful for Abbotsford to be able to show such a fascinating painting.'It will intrigue and delight our visitors. To think that we are publicly displaying the watercolour for the very first time since it waas painted by Turner is also tremendously exciting.'

title: Scottish Natural Heritage draws rules unlikely event CATCHES Nessie
story: The original Loch Ness Monster sighting: Officials have put a plan in place if the Loch Ness Monster is ever caughtScotland's first minister Nicola Sturgeon also said she believes that the monster exists in the water.So if Nessie was discovered, SNH said it would 'dust off' the plan. The code of practice was created to offer protection to new species discovered in the loch, which also includes a monster. It states that a DNA sample should be taken from any new creature, so that scientists can study it. Loch Ness monster: Research team to examine water´s...Is this the Loch Ness Monster? Tourist films 'creature'...Share this articleThen it should be released back into the loch with measures put in place to make sure it is not disturbed - as it would be an extremely rare species needing conservation. Nick Halfhide, of SNH, the organisation that promotes Scottish wildlife and natural habitats, said the 17-year-old code of practice remained relevant today.He said: 'There was a lot of activity on the loch at the time about Nessie.'So, partly serious and partly for a bit of fun, we drew up a contingency plan about how we would help Nessie if and when she was found.          The code of practice was created to offer protection to new species discovered in the loch, which also includes a monsterLast month, a global team of scientists, known as the Super Natural History team, will use environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling of the waters to identify tiny DNA remnants left behind by life in the Highlands loch.The study was led by Professor Neil Gemmell of the University of Otago, New Zealand.He said he would be surprised if there is any evidence of DNA sequences similar to those likely to come from a large extinct marine reptile, the so called 'Jurassic hypothesis', but is open minded about what they might find.

title: Primark investigates 1 hair bobble four year old girls blonde locks turn GREEN
story: Lowri Jones, pictured with her daughter Celyn, left, bought the young girl a bobble to keep her hair tied up when she splashed around in the swimming pool          However, the £1 bobble from Primark bled its dye changing Celyn's hair colour          Ms Jones said she washed her daughter's hair several times but it is still bright greenNow her parents Stephen and Lowri Jones from Llangefni are warning others about using the £1 hair ties from the discount fashion store, which is now investigating.They are worried that another child could swallow the dye. The couple say they have tried everything to remove the dye and although the colour is fading, it is still visible in Celyn's bright blonde hair some five days later.Lost Turner masterpiece could fetch £230,000 for shrewd...Share this articleLowri said: 'On Monday, I put Celyn's swimming costume on her after smothering her in sun cream.'I tied her hair up with one of the bobbles we'd bought from Primark to keep her hair out of her face.'Around 20 minutes later, I started to notice her hair was turning green.  Ms Jones paid £1 for the bobble which transformed her daughter's hair'I took the bobble out and the green dye just spread throughout her hair.'I didn't think much about it at first, thinking the water in the paddling pool would wash it out, but it didn't.'The mum-of-five said she has since tried all different kinds of shampoos and has even used Fairy Liquid on her daughter's hair.Her 33-year-old mother added: 'Celyn's hair is very light so you can see there'sstill quite a lot of green in it.'Her hair does look a mess and she's having to go to school with it like that.'I've explained to the teachers but Celyn is loving it.' Celyn's father Stephen said he had emailed Primark to complain.He said: 'We can't even take Celyn to the hairdressers to have the greencut out because it's all around the middle of her head.'It's quite embarrassing. It's just a mess and doesn't look good on us as parents either.'It's very lucky the dye didn't enter my daughter's eyes or mouth - whoknows what kind of damage that would have caused?'I want to know what Primark is doing about it as I wouldn't like it to happen to another child.'A Primark spokeswoman said: 'The quality of our products is extremely important to us.'I can confirm that an email has been received and Primark will investigate this complaint.'An email sent to Stephen from Primark in response to his complaint asks him to post the bobbles to their officers to be tested by their technical department.

title: What wives 1966 think todays World Cup WAGs
story: From left: Alan Ball's girlfriend Lesley Newton Geoff Hurst's wife Judith Nobby Stiles's wife Kay Bobby Charlton's wife Norma Ray Wilson's wife Pat Terry Paine's wife Carol and Gordon Banks's wife Ursula on the eve of the 1966 World Cup final  How times have changed.Mrs Vardy has spoken openly about today’s players’ sex lives. She has said she and her husband ‘struggle’ to be intimate during the tournament: ‘There is no sex ban, but I think we’d struggle to do it anyway with the kids around — it wouldn’t work logistically!’Mrs Hunt does not mention Mrs Vardy — who has appeared on ITV’s I’m A Celebrity — by name but it seems she’s not a fan of the more lairy type of modern footballer’s wife.Speaking of the 2018 WAGs, she says: ‘You have to have your boobs done and false hair and false teeth and false nails. They’re not real, are they?‘The way that the WAGs are seems to be based on how people on reality TV look. They seem to copy that look and not want to be your ordinary grassroots people.‘Well, I don’t know how you come home from all that flash and live an ordinary life.’Lucky shirts washed, BBQs cleaned and beers in: Excitement...From awkward schoolboys to England heroes: Never before seen...EXCLUSIVE: Sweden's WAGS will stay at the same hotel as the...Share this articleToday, it’s all blinging manicures, designer clothes from head to foot and high-maintenance hair. Players, such as Dele Alli, have models as girlfriends — in his case one who specialises in lingerie.These are lifestyles and behaviour utterly alien to the wives of 1966.The Football Association even excluded them from the victory champagne reception at London’s Royal Garden Hotel in Kensington. Instead, the wives — and one fiancee — dined separately in the chop house upstairs. Their husbands came up to collect them at around midnight.Kathleen Peters, the wife of midfielder Martin Peters, said: ‘We were overwhelmed and just sat in the hotel room, staring at his medal like two kids. We didn’t even drink champagne — I think I made us a cup of tea.’One wife was absent, Jack Charlton’s wife Pat, who — now 83 — likes to joke that she is the ‘oldest WAG in the world’.She watched the World Cup Final on a black-and-white TV in her modest semi-detached house in Leeds with her mother. ‘Of course we were very proud of them, but we were not involved like the wives and girlfriends are these days at all,’ she says.          WAGs on a night out in St Petersburg. From left: Millie Savage, Gemma Acton, Megan Davison, Becky Vardy, Annabel Peyton, Fern Hawkins, Shannon Horlock, Annie Kilner and Lucia LoiLike current England captain Harry Kane’s fiancee, Katie Goodland, Pat was pregnant and opted to stay at home for medical reasons. ‘I watched it at home because I was about to have a baby. I already had two children.‘I wanted to go to the final, but the medical advice was against it and you don’t want to go into labour in the middle of the World Cup Final at Wembley.’She adds: ‘I know that some of the girls were upset because after the final they could not sit with the husbands but had to go into another room for dinner. They felt it was not right, stuck in a different room, like you are nothing. But that was the way it was.’Pat, married to Jack for 60 years, remembers he rang her about an hour after the match, and came home the next day — stopping at a transport cafe for a plate of egg and chips.The separations while the tournament was on were hard, she said. ‘They would go off for two or three weeks before the World Cup and you wouldn’t see them.’But that was the way England manager Alf Ramsey insisted that it should be. He didn’t want his players to have any contact with their wives — they were allowed phone calls and letters only.Patricia Hunt, who was orced from Roger in 1981, explains: ‘We had a very different relationship with the management. They kept the wives and families at a distance. We were definitely not involved or invited. Our role was not even considered.’She seems astonished that one of this year’s players, Fabian Delph, returned from Russia to the UK to be with his wife for the birth of their third child.‘If that had happened in Alf Ramsey’s day, he would have said: ‘‘Go home...and don’t come back after.’’ It would not even have been considered a possibility.          Roger Hunt and wife Patricia pictured a few weeks after England's triumph in the 1966 final‘Football is not just a game any more,’ says Pat. ‘The money they earn, the cars they drive, the mansions they live in and the lifestyles they lead are totally different from the way it was for us.’This much is true — the England team were paid a tiny fraction of current wages.Martin Peters earned around £120 a week at Tottenham (the equivalent of £1,770). Harry Kane, who plays for the same club, is on £200,000 a week.Pat Hunt says: ‘We were ordinary people. Your husband was playing a game of football, but it was no big fuss made. I would have hated to have been looked at and analysed and watched as the WAGs are, but now it’s all big money and celebrity.‘Rebekah Vardy flies out with all the family on a private jet, then she’s on the telly on Loose Women and is out until 3am or 4am, and it’s all about publicity.‘I suppose they do it and absolutely love it, and good luck to them, if they can handle it.’Tina Moore, married to 1966 England captain Bobby until 1986, agrees. ‘We didn’t have anything like their money, but we did have a wonderful life. Would I like to be a WAG today? I don’t know, to be honest. My husband was handsome and charismatic, but you never had too much concern (about predatory female rivals).‘Nowadays it’s horrendous — women pursue footballers because they know that they could end up with a great lifestyle. I wish them luck with it.’

title: Boycott boycott Rio Ferdinand enjoys cup tea slice cake Vladimir Putin
story: Former England internationals Alex Scott, second left, and Rio Ferdinand, right, were pictured with Vladimir Putin centre, despite a boycott of the tournament by British politicians and members of the Royal Family over the ongoing dispute with RussiaAnd Ferdinand was sitting just two spaces away from Putin as they chatted around a grand, white table. They had visited a park near where the Skripals were found collapsed in March.          Rio Ferdinand was joined at the event by fellow former England star Alex ScottBoth victims had collapsed, hallucinating and foaming at the mouth, on Saturday. Police confirmed they had been exposed to Novichok, which is one of the most toxic substances known to man.Home Secretary Sajid Javid blamed the Kremlin for the trail of devastation and said it had been treating Britain as ‘dumping grounds for poison’.Russia accused the UK of staging the crisis to ruin the World Cup and stoke ‘anti-Russia hysteria’.Police are continuing to search for the item contaminated with the nerve agent, which the couple are believed to have handled.Police initially thought the couple had taken a contaminated batch of drugs. But Wiltshire Police then launched a major investigation after experts warned they were suffering the symptoms of nerve agent poisoning.

title: Two cats litter born without legs
story: Frog the tabby cat and his brother Newt were both born 10 weeks ago without rear legs          Despite their lack of rear legs, both cats are perfectly able to walk around without any pain          Animal rescuers said the kittens received their names as there are frogs and newts at the centreAnd they are being well cared for at the Rescue Me Animal Sanctuary in Liverpool, which took them in ten days ago after the owner advertised them on social media.The sanctuary is unaware of any other two-legged cats born in the UK.Thought to be ten weeks old, they got their names because there are lots of frogs and newts at the rescue centre.Because they are from the same litter, it is believed inbreeding may have led to them being born without their back legs. Sanctuary founder Steph Taylor said: ‘It doesn’t seem to affect them at all, they are scratching up scratch posts. They even manage to jump down from levels as well. They are doing really well.’Frog and Newt will be kept in long-term care to assess their progress. Because they are thriving, there are no plans to fit them with wheels, which can happen with animals that lose their legs.The sanctuary looks after some 500 animals a year, with each cat or kitten rescued costing it around £60. To offer support or make a donation, visit @RescueMeAnimal on Facebook.

title: The tragic truth cousin marriages
story: Hiba Maroof (centre) with her parents, Maroof and Nuzhat, at home in BradfordHer uncle, Younis, hopes that Hiba does so and follows his family tradition.Indeed, four of his own five children have wed close relatives. However, Hiba’s father is unsure. And her mother is very much against her daughter marrying such a close relative because her own first marriage — to a cousin — ended in orce.Hiba, single and a student at the University of Leeds, faces a common dilemma. Her story came to public attention because she featured in a BBC documentary called Should I Marry My Cousin?, which looked at the custom of cousin marriage.Relationships described as ‘consanguineous’ are those between couples who are at least second cousins or more closely related. The practice has been legal in Britain for more than 400 years, but is considered one of society’s last taboos.In British Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities, marriage between cousins is designed to strengthen the family and keep wealth intact.But there are massive health risks involved for the children of such couples. And when they are tragically born with disabilities, it is taxpayers who are left to pick up the huge costs of their NHS treatment, which can run into millions over a lifetime.Police launch massive manhunt for pensioner, 70, who has...Larissa Beilby's accused killer 'put a loaded gun in the...Share this articleNew official figures shown to the Mail reveal a worrying picture across England. Shockingly, cousin marriages are a key factor in an average of two child deaths every week.This figure is derived from the fact that a total of 545 boys or girls born to closely related couples have died in childhood during the past five years, according to the Department for Education, which collates data from Child Death Overview Panels in every council area. (It is the job of these panels to examine the deaths of any child under the age of 18.)Thousands more children of consanguineous marriages survive, but with appalling physical or mental problems. These include blindness, deafness, blood ailments, heart or kidney failure, lung or liver problems and a myriad of often incurable and complex neurological or brain disorders.According to a report for the BBC’s Newsnight, British Pakistanis are 13 times more likely to have children with genetic disorders than the general population.They are responsible for three percent of all births, but produce just under a third of all British children with such health problems.In Birmingham, around one in ten children from first cousin marriages either dies in infancy or develops a serious life-long disability caused by genetic ailments, according to health officials in the city, where half the mothers of Pakistani origin are married to a close relative.Meanwhile, a research document by the NHS-funded Enhanced Genetic Services Project reveals that in Birmingham in 2009-2010, the combined infant stillbirth and death rate ‘definitely or probably’ due to genetic disorders inherited from Pakistani cousin parents was 38 times higher than that among white European babies in the city.The report — one of the most thorough into this health and social problem — says: ‘Almost a third of the affected children die before five years of age.Most of the survivors suffer chronic disability, and they are cared for by their families, posing tremendous emotional and financial strain.’Up in Bradford, where teenager Hiba Maroof lives, doctors and nurses have told me paediatric wards look after numerous children who are unable to speak, and are fed through tubes.

A fan looks at the screen in awe at the wedding of Kerry and Keelan Hall          Fans tuck into drinks and dinner at the wedding reception - which is showing the England game in the background          GOAL! Fans at the wedding of Mr and Mrs Hall celebrate the goal as England go 2-0 aheadSpeaking to Good Morning Britain Mr Hall said: 'There has been a lot of debate over the last two weeks or so. Originally we weren't going to play it because Kerry wasn't really impressed by the idea.'But after the England game on Tuesday she has really bought into it and came around to it and made the decision yesterday morning'. The new Mr and Mrs Hall were cheered by friends and family just before the game starts before the wedding party settle down for food, drink and football.Mr Hall said: 'We arrive here at 2.50pm so the guests will be seated and we'll be toasted in ready for kick off. It'll be played throughout the meal. We're going to embrace the atmosphere and hopefully it will make it a better day'.           No need for speeches! The bride and groom put on the game as fans watch Maguire score          Keelan Hall and Kerry Warren, pictured with their son, will show the England to guests at their wedding tomorrow  after the bride-to-beFans in Croydon cheer massively as England scores 2nd goalSearch teams seek alternative exits for trapped soccer teamDawn Sturgess captured on CCTV hours before 'Novichok' poisoningEngland fans at Silverstone celebrate first goal against SwedenRevellers enjoy the 2018 Pride festivities in central London'Football is NOT coming home': Noel Gallagher irritates fans at concertDash cam captures carpark crash that has ided the internetCouple say they've decided to show the World Cup at their weddingEngland fans cheers as Maguire opens the scoring for EnglandRescue mission: new footage surfaces from depths of flooded Thai caveSerena Williams tends to daughter before going to win at Wimbledon    Initially Kerry 'wasn't impressed' with Keelan's idea (pictured together) but changed her mind after England's win over ColombiaNotts County season-ticket holder Carl Younger, 54, didn't expect England to reach the quarter-finals when he set the date to tie the knot with Angela Laud, 53.Now family and friends are set to miss out on the big game with his son Josh, who is the best man on the day, asking: 'How can you do this to me, Dad?!'Angela, who is a support worker for people with disabilities, said: 'We picked this date because we met on July 8 and we thought Saturday would be better than Sunday. The vows will only take about 45 minutes so we are hoping they will be able to watch the second half.'Carl's sister's children are not happy and my son is not happy and Carl's son who is a big football fan said - 'how can you do this to me, dad?''My nephews are also massive football fans. It might be ladies only at this wedding the way it is going. I am just hoping that the first half will be boring so they don't miss anything.'Newlyweds are told with just three days' notice they can't...Neymar's ROLLING home! Football fans worldwide fail to hide...'Football's Coming Home!': Prince William speaks for the...It's coming homeware! Pranksters raid IKEA and label...Share this articleThe couple, from Sneinton, Nottinghamshire, tied the knot at Bridgford Hall registry office at 3pm, before the wedding reception at Copper in West Bridgford.Builder Carl said: 'The World Cup did not cross my mind at the time. I did not miss a Notts County game last season so when it comes to football I will watch anything.'I have watched nearly every game of the World Cup. When we beat Colombia I was over the moon and then I looked at the list and saw we were playing Sweden on Saturday.'I really hope that we win and this might be a good luck charm for England that we are getting married at the same time.'          Friends Shaun Cureton and James Cureton with Angela Laud and Carl YoungerRegistrar Hazel Tait, who married the happy couple on Saturday, said: 'Angela and Carl are trying to put measures in place for themselves and their guests.'In terms of the registrar we will be working and we have a lot of weddings that day.'We have 20 weddings across the southern part of the county alone. We are hoping that the weddings at the end of the day will be able to fill us in on how we are doing.'However, another couple have rearranged their wedding.  Groom Nick Hawley has even postponed the wedding reception until after 5.30pm in case the knockout game goes to penalties.          Sue Potter and Nick Hawley pictured outside the Picnic Stop, which Sue runs          As soon as Eric Dier scored the winning penalty for England in Tuesday night's cliffhanger with Columbia, bride, Sue Potter resigned herself to having all her wedding plans thrown up in the airAs soon as Eric Dier scored the winning penalty for England in Tuesday night's cliffhanger with Columbia, bride, Sue Potter resigned herself to having all her wedding plans thrown up in the air.Football-mad Nick was almost instantly on the phone to wedding planners to rearrange the times of their wedding and reception.Sue said: 'England had better bring the World Cup home after all the sacrifice I have made on my big day.'I knew as soon as they won that it was all going to get changed.'Up until then it was all going swimmingly.'I knew it wouldn't go to plan because on Tuesday, as well as the game, one of the bridesmaids dresses went missing and our dog sitter had to cancel. So it was going to happen whatever.'          Groom Nick Hawley has even postponed the wedding reception until after 5.30pm in case the knockout game goes to penaltiesSue, 43, the owner of The Picnic Stop sandwich bar and cafe in Cleethorpes said: 'Nick got on to the lady at the hotel and brought it forward to 2.30pm and then got the reception and speeches put back to 5.30pm.'Despite the upheaval, Sue said she was excited about tying the knot with Nick after being together 18 years.'We decided to do it this year. Nick wanted a massive wedding but I have persuaded him to keep it small and there are 29 of us going to Gretna Green,' said Sue.'I love him because of his weird sense of humour and he makes me laugh everyday and he is kind and very sociable. Everything turns into a massive party when he is around,' the bride said. Sue said nothing was going to get in the way of their honeymoon - not even the start of Grimsby Town FC's season.Nick will miss the start of the season and the derby match with Lincoln City at Blundell Park on August 18 at 1pm.'Nothing is going to get in the way of the honeymoon. He is not crossing that line,' said Sue. Window cleaner, Nick runs his son Sam's under 16 football squad Sussex Elite Windows.The happy couple will be joined by daughter Ellie Stevenson, 24 and Libby Hawley, 13.Nick said: 'As soon as England won I was straight on to the wedding planner. But it is not as easy as you think. The photographer is into football too so was happy to accommodate us.'They were all very thoughtful and moved the wedding at The Courtyard forward and the reception at Greens of Gretna to 5.30pm.'We are massive England fans.'            Katrina and Samuel Williams were married at a ceremony attended by their parents in Cyprus last month. Their plans for a reception in the UK have been hit by the England match She added: 'We can't get hold of everyone that's due to come so I've had to drive about telling people the news.'I've found the whole thing traumatising - we have a toddler to look after and I work full time as a nurse and just don't need this extra stress.'The couple believe the venue's change of plans is due to the England match. But the bar insists it never offered the large function room that Katrina and Samuel, 31, say they requested.          They believe the decision not to give them the room they wanted is due to the England gameA spokesman said: 'It was unfortunate that on this occasion, communication between ourselves and the party involved was delayed and details were not finalised until just over a week before the event. We would like to make it clear that this was not a failure on our part.'Due to this delay, the apparent mix-up over the function room offered only came to light very late in the day.'We have done our utmost to find an alternative solution and it is a shame that we have not been able to do so.'England's quarter final tie, which kicks off at 3pm, has caused headaches for scores of couples planning their big days.            Humber Dock Bar and Grill in Hull insists the dispute is the result of an administrative mix-upOne couple, from Norwich, have arranged for the game to be screened at their wedding.Hayley Cullum, 31, and her fiancée, James Adams, 33, will wed at 2pm today - and have their photos taken at the same time as kick off.  'I'm not bothered by it but all of the men on both sides love football, especially Adam's mates who cry over it, so I thought instead of losing half of my wedding party I would put a TV up' she told the Eastern Daily Press. Ahead of the game, one senior Church of England cleric has warned people not to watch the game on mobile phones or tablets if they are in church.One couple have installed a satellite dish so their guests can watch the quarter-final - but they will have to wait until after the speeches and watch the game 'as live' two hours later. Elsewhere gig-goers at the British Summer Time in Hyde Park didn't arrive until at least 5pm - three hours after it starts - because 'unpatriotic' organisers aren't showing the football and won't allow people to come and go from the site.And organisers of London's Pride festival are considering putting up giant screens so the tens of thousands taking part on Saturday afternoon can cheer England on rather than stay away.            Matt Yeo and fiancee Sophie Wood (pictured) are installing satellite dishes at their wedding reception but guests will have to wait until 5pm and watch the match 'as live' Graphic designer Matt Yeo told the Daily Telegraph: 'It has changed our plans quite dramatically. My fiancee Sophie is not a football fan and is very against the idea of having any football because you don't want to detract from the big day. 'But I felt that everyone will be looking at their phones or feeling like they wish they were watching it.'Matt and fiancee Sophie Wood, both 30, will instead set up a television for their guests to watch the match at 5pm, instead of having the speeches ruined by the distraction of the World Cup. Guests will be told to turn their phones off so they can watch the game later without knowing the result. Meanwhile groom-to-be Carl Gould, who finds himself in a similar position, told the Guardian he would not install screens as 'we're not getting married in a Wetherspoons'.    He said he hoped the wedding day would bring the England team luck, saying: 'If we could have a wedding win, and an England win – that would be ideal.' Bride-to-be Jodie Houlston, from Lincolnshire, said: 'OK England, you're starting to worry me now.'If you're kicking a ball around a bit of grass upstages me on my wedding day I may have to have the first a strop of my life.'        Wedding plans have been thrown into chaos because of the big game at 3pm on SaturdayDanni Jordan, of Ipswich, said her brother had posted a Facebook status asking his fiancée if they could move their wedding to Sunday, so he doesn't miss the match.   Ashleigh Marie said: 'When the England game will be playing during your wedding... woo, nothing like paying all that money to have missing guests.'  Groom-to-be Gary Snoad tweeted: 'My own wedding clashing with the big game on Saturday - what have I done? Apologies to the English contingent, definitely the Welsh family side that picked the date.' And Zoey Olivia, of Watford, added: 'Just realised I'm at a wedding on Saturday and England are playing... I'm so torn. I hope there's a TV.'Sandra Millar, the Church of England's head of 'life events', said: 'For those attending a wedding service at 3pm, I'd strongly encourage you to make sure you are fully on-side with the happy couple and switch off your mobile phone in advance.'Rev Millar added that while guests 'may be forgiven' for checking the score at the reception - doing this in church should be given the 'red card'.She told the Daily Telegraph: 'For those getting married on Saturday, like England fans you might experience a few nerves - but you can be sure that it will also be the best day of your life, with memories to cherish. 'Who knows, come 6pm, that may be something you share with the rest of the nation too'.  Though she is English, bride-to-be Carmel, 27, from the Midlands, says there would not be any options for fans to watch the game at her wedding to Killian, 30, in South Wales on Saturday.'We don't have the facilities to do so in the venue, so that's a good excuse.'No-one has directly asked for us to put it on but there have been several jokes and suggestions, if you know what I mean. People who would like to have it on but don't want to straight out ask or come across as rude or anything.'Asked how she would react if anyone sneaked off to catch a glimpse of the television, Carmel said: 'I'd probably be like, 'Are you serious?!''I don't mind people checking the scores or having a quick look on their phones while we're all milling about but if anyone goes off to the accommodation I won't be best pleased!'It's at 3 so it sits quite nicely between our ceremony and dinner. As long as they're around and engaging, I'm happy to have a little give and take,' she said.'I think all our friends and family are pretty respectful so I don't think they'd push it really.''There's been some heated debates'George Morey, 25, and the soon-to-be Aimee Morey, 24, have managed to secure a screen for their wedding reception at a golf club in Swanley, Kent, and say 'dinner will be pushed'.'There's certainly been some heated debates about the game but she's come round to the idea of it now,' said George, a Millwall fan who works as a trainee lift engineer.'If we win it will just add to the atmosphere of the day. We can't wait.'I've had this in my head that England will play this day since the draw in December.'He added: 'I was thinking it would be the Germans in the quarter-final but I'll take Sweden and a first semi-final in 28 years instead.'Couple who began romance aged 13 allow wedding guests to watch England match during vows | Great Yarmouth News - Great Yarmouth MercuryNorwich couple to screen World Cup game at wedding | Latest Norfolk and Suffolk News - Eastern Daily Press

title: Seal chases woman street
story: This is the hilarious moment a seal was spotted defending his owner's turf in the middle of an unsuspecting Australian suburb (pictured)  Video footage reveals a seal who sat in the centre of a home's front yard in Beachport, South Australia engaging in a stare-off with a female passerbySeal pups play tug of war with a sheet of plastic washed up...Give us a lift, mate! Ship picks up a hitchhiking seal that...Share this article    (stock image) New Zealand fur sealThey're the largest of all fur seals The sea mammals raise their body on their front flippers to move forwardFur seals can e to depths of up to 200m These seals are found in the islands of Bass Strait and parts of Tasmania, Victoria's south, islands of South Australia and southern New South Wales They eat bony fish, squid and octopus                         The seal and woman appeared to stare each other down before the seal played 'security guard.'The seal started to chase the woman down the street.The standoff between the woman and suspected Australian fur seal was sighted in the small  coastal town, 379km south-east of Adelaide.It comes after another seal was spotted in the upper-market Sydney suburb of Rush Cutter's bay in the city's east.A fur seal was sighted sunbathing in a park in the exclusive eastern suburb of Adelaide. A portion of the park was blocked off by council staff while the seal napped in front of the multi-million-dollar waterfront views.A City Of Sydney spokesperson at the time told the ABC barriers were set up as a precaution to protect the public as well as encourage the seal to move away from the site. Sydney Harbour fur seal blocked from returning to Rushcutters Bay Park - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

Bonding time: A day before Fern had shared a loved-up snap of her exploring Saint Petersberg with long-term boyfriend and Leicester City defender Harry Maguire          Tough times: Elsewhere Fern was begroaning her early start as she took to social media to share a snap of the dreary runway while layering the time over the top of the shot - revealing it was 7.52amEngland supporters have been queuing up for four hours outside pubs in boiling heat to watch the Three Lions take on Sweden in their World Cup Quarter-final clash.Today's match at the Samara Arena will bring the country to a standstill as a total of 32 million viewers - the biggest TV audience in living memory - tune in.  Fervent football fans were pictured standing outside pubs in London as early as 10am this morning in sizzling 91.5F (33C) heat to secure a space inside.           These supporters have been queuing up since 10am this morning to get into The George pub in London Bridge to watch today's tie          The fervent fans baked in sizzling 91.5F (33C) heat as they waited to secure a space inside the traditional English pubEngland’s victories so far in Russia have sparked scenes of wild celebration here and the atmosphere today will be electric - especially if they progress.The Three Lions are attempting to reach their first World Cup semi-final for 28 years.  Elsewhere, crowds have flocked to outdoor big screens in cities including London, Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, Bristol, Exeter and Leeds to make the most of the beautiful weather while watching the game. team's current most viewed game ever.But the game against Sweden today is tipped to top the Italia 90 viewing figures, with up to 30m people expected to watch the game. Despite England being mere hours away from their big World Cup clash against Sweden, Sir Bobby Charlton was spotted signing autographs and joining in on the fun.The World Cup winner seemed to be relaxed ahead a big day of sport for England with the World Cup quarter-final later and Kyle Edmund set to take on three-time Wimbledon champion Novak Djokovic.It remains to be seen whether he will be leaving Wimbledon early with the stars including Sir Mo Farah, boxer David Haye, Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill and former cricketer Andrew Strauss, on another scorching day at Wimbledon.At the Rose and Crown pub in Wimbledon village, scores of fans have gathered for the England game, including many who have left Wimbledon.Those who have tickets for Saturday's tennis have been issued with pink and blue re-entry wristbands.There were chants of 'get the tennis off' as fans waited eagerly for the football to be put on the big screens.Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, has seats on Court One but has left to watch the football.He events.With so many watching the match, the nation came to a halt today with roads, high streets and train stations empty throughout the 90 minutes of the quarter-final.The RAC said it expects 'the title: Tesco targets singletons eating smaller portions shrunk bottles wine
story: Tesco has boosted its single-serve range by close to 40 per cent this year to 430 products          Customers have been buying more ready meals and salads as they increasingly eat by themselvesKate Ewart, Tesco’s head of product development, who is based in Welwyn Garden City, said: ‘It’s about offering choice. Time-pressed customers want to find healthy, quick and convenient meals in the size that matches the occasion.’Tesco is tapping into the meals-for-one market by offering shrunken products, including small bottles of Sauvignon Blanc, slices of wood-fired pizza and pitta breads sold in packets of two rather than six.  How will people Instagram their meals? Restaurant takes...Tesco, Sainsbury's, Waitrose and Iceland are forced to...Share this articleCustomers have been buying more ready meals and salads as they increasingly eat by themselves - particularly as the number of orces are at their highest in England and Wales since 2009. At the same time, marriages are decreasing, especially among 45-64 year olds. A year ago, Premier Foods launched Batchelors Pasta ‘n’ Sauce in single serve pots to ‘target time-poor customers’.Joanna Parman, an analyst at data firm Nielsen, said that smaller households have 'a lot of buying power and shop very differently to family shoppers'. The firm's recent shopper poll found that nearly 20 per cent of shoppers wanted to buy smaller pack sizes.Tesco targets growing number of Britons who eat or live alone | Business | The Guardian

title: GoFundMe page raises 5 000 devastated family Alesha MacPhail
story: A fundraising page for the family of murdered Alesha MacPhail has raised more than £5,000 in just two daysPolice launched a massive investigation and a 16-year-old boy has appeared at Greenock Sheriff Court today after being arrested and charged with her rape and murder.A target of £5,000 had been set but in just 48 hours hundreds of donations saw the total soar to £5,606.The GoFundMe page says: 'A suffering family, her friends and the people of the Isle of Bute have just lost a young child.'She is Alesha MacPhail, and because the loss of a child is a grief that never ends, the island of Bute, as well as her remaining family and close friends, will forever endure this hardship.          The body of Alesha MacPhail was found in woodland in the grounds of a former hotel'To assist this hurting family, we ask that you assist with costs to take just a small part of their burden away, and that you might serve as a source of strength for her immediate and extended family.'All donations will be forwarded to assist this family during this delicate and painful period.'Heartfelt tributes have also been left by well-wishers on the fundraising page.Amanda McCann posted: 'Heartbreaking. Scotland has lost a beautiful wee lassie. Rest in peace Alesha. All my love to the family xxx.'Sandra Murdoch wrote: 'RIP sweet angel, fly high beautiful you were such a delight. Miss your happy wee smile xx.'While Alison Carstairs said: 'Fly high sweet angel. Bute and it's many friends will never forget you.'Earlier, Detective Superintendent Stuart Houston said: 'I'd like to take this opportunity to personally thank Alesha's family who have shown incredible bravery through what has been an unimaginable ordeal during these past few days.'I'd also like to thank local people for all their support and assistance during this major investigation on the island. 'The response to our appeals was significant both from those living here and the wider community of Scotland.'The people of the Isle of Bute have rallied together since Alesha was first reported missing on Monday morning and I would stress that social media speculation relating to members of the community is both misleading and inaccurate.    Police search streets and houses on the Isle of Bute yesterday as part of the investigation          The teenager was arrested on suspicion of murder before being charged yesterday'The family has also received considerable support from Alesha's home town of Airdrie which was reflected in the memorial service held at her school.'Officers and staff from across Police Scotland and the Scottish Police Authority have been involved in what has been a difficult and challenging investigation during which they have worked tirelessly to bring us to where we are.'The campaign page can be found by logging on to https:www.gofundme.comlove-for-alesha
