title: Lost Turner masterpiece fetch 230 000 f
story: An unsigned painting by JMW Turner discovered in Scotland is believed to be worth six figures          Kirsty Archer-Thompson confirmed that the unsigned painting is a genuine turnerShe has confidently declared it to be an original by JMW Turner, one of the most celebrated British artists of all time.The watercolour is now on exhibition at Abbotsford, Sir Walter Scott's home in the Scottish Borders from 1812 to his death in 1832.Turner, who lived and worked in London, was known to have visited Abbotsford in 1831 as a guest of Scott and the painting is believed to be one of his early watercolour works of this view of Abbotsford.What do you do with a drunken seagull? Birds are left...STEAM trains! London tube passengers suffer in unbearable...Share this articleThey believe it could have been painted between 1831-1833. Kirsty Archer-Thompson, collection and interpretation manager, at Abbotsford is the Scott expert, who confirmed the painting as a Turner.She said: 'I'm willing to stick my neck on the line that it is a genuine Turner. We believe it to be one of his earlier watercolours.'          Libby Sheldon, pictured, agrees the painting is a genuine TurnerMs Archer-Thompson revealed that cross-border cooperation had resulted in the lost Turner coming to light.She said: 'The private collector of the lost Turner watercolour is English.We met him through a Scottish connection, who is another art collector.''I first saw the painting in March at the collector's private residence.'He bought the painting a few years ago but has been researching it because he wanted to find out more as he thought there was something special about it.'I knew it was a genuine Turner. I was completely moved when I held it in my hands. It is something to hold it in your hand rather than behind a glass, which is great about my job. This is probably the highlight of my career.'The private collector paid peanuts for it - a two-figure sum - only for a national gem to be discovered.'Extensive archival research was undertaken to build up a case for why this was a genuine Turner painting from his life and time at Abbotsford.Her role was using her expert knowledge in the subject to help the owner unravel the story behind the painting of Scott's home. Combining that with the scientific study of the painting has enabled Ms Archer-Thompson to make the case.Ms Archer-Thompson is convinced it is a Turner because a pencil sketch, which can only be seen by infra-red imaging reveals the artist's original sketch. This has been adapated and changed siginficantly in the paint.The type of paper used for the watercolour also matches Turner's use of materials but the main focus was on the date of the frame and the paint.The scene of the Tuner painting is also found in the engraved commemorative book after Scott's death.Ms Archer-Thompson added: 'Not very long ago another lost Turner watercolour appeared and was sold for £230,000.'The tiny watercolour, which is poket sized, measures at 5.5 inches by 3.5 inches.Libby Sheldon, a painting analyst expert, 'supports the theory' the Turner is a genuine.Ms Archer-Thompson, added: 'All of this analysis, including work by painting expert Libby Sheldon, demonstrates that it was executed by an astonishingly skilled hand.'          The painting is believed to have been painted at the Scottish home of Sir Walter Scott, picturedWhen Turner stayed at Scott's house in August 1831, the writer showed the renowned painter his art collection, amongst which is believed to be a view of Abbotsford and the River Tweed by Scottish artist Elizabeth Nasmyth.Ms Archer-Thompson said: 'This painting is from exactly the same vantage point we believe Turner painted.'Scott had a personal attachment to the Nasmyth painting and its composition and my theory is that this gave Turner the idea to compose the same scene, which he based on sketches in the Abbotsford sketchbook used during his visit in 1831.'Abbotsford House Trust chairman James Holloway, a former director of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery in Edinburgh, added: 'It is wonderful for Abbotsford to be able to show such a fascinating painting.'It will intrigue and delight our visitors. To think that we are publicly displaying the watercolour for the very first time since it waas painted by Turner is also tremendously exciting.'

title: Primark investigates 1 hair bobble four year old girls blonde locks turn GREEN
story: Lowri Jones, pictured with her daughter Celyn, left, bought the young girl a bobble to keep her hair tied up when she splashed around in the swimming pool          However, the £1 bobble from Primark bled its dye changing Celyn's hair colour          Ms Jones said she washed her daughter's hair several times but it is still bright greenNow her parents Stephen and Lowri Jones from Llangefni are warning others about using the £1 hair ties from the discount fashion store, which is now investigating.They are worried that another child could swallow the dye. The couple say they have tried everything to remove the dye and although the colour is fading, it is still visible in Celyn's bright blonde hair some five days later.Lost Turner masterpiece could fetch £230,000 for shrewd...Share this articleLowri said: 'On Monday, I put Celyn's swimming costume on her after smothering her in sun cream.'I tied her hair up with one of the bobbles we'd bought from Primark to keep her hair out of her face.'Around 20 minutes later, I started to notice her hair was turning green.  Ms Jones paid £1 for the bobble which transformed her daughter's hair'I took the bobble out and the green dye just spread throughout her hair.'I didn't think much about it at first, thinking the water in the paddling pool would wash it out, but it didn't.'The mum-of-five said she has since tried all different kinds of shampoos and has even used Fairy Liquid on her daughter's hair.Her 33-year-old mother added: 'Celyn's hair is very light so you can see there'sstill quite a lot of green in it.'Her hair does look a mess and she's having to go to school with it like that.'I've explained to the teachers but Celyn is loving it.' Celyn's father Stephen said he had emailed Primark to complain.He said: 'We can't even take Celyn to the hairdressers to have the greencut out because it's all around the middle of her head.'It's quite embarrassing. It's just a mess and doesn't look good on us as parents either.'It's very lucky the dye didn't enter my daughter's eyes or mouth - whoknows what kind of damage that would have caused?'I want to know what Primark is doing about it as I wouldn't like it to happen to another child.'A Primark spokeswoman said: 'The quality of our products is extremely important to us.'I can confirm that an email has been received and Primark will investigate this complaint.'An email sent to Stephen from Primark in response to his complaint asks him to post the bobbles to their officers to be tested by their technical department.

title: How photo finally trapped Britains wanted conman Mark Acklom
story: Acklom (right), caught on camera by one of his alleged victims at a cafe in Geneva in 2017What followed, said witnesses, was like ‘something out of a Netflix drama’.‘I saw three cars — two undercover cars and one big official one with markings,’ noted one neighbour. ‘They blocked all the ways in and out. Then I saw the police jump out and run to the building.‘They split up: some went to the upper road and some took the lower road and some went by the lake. It was getting dark. We were sitting there thinking “Should we be afraid?” — because one of the policemen took his gun out.’Then, leaping from the first-floor balcony, the man attempted to flee, jumping down to the lawn below.Luckily, officers who had been staking out the flat for days were ready and waiting — wrestling him to the ground and securing him with handcuffs.He has been under lock and key ever since. And, if the authorities have their way, he will remain so for some considerable time.Because the smooth-talking ‘business executive’ is none other than Mark Acklom, Britain’s most wanted conman.He’s been on the run for more than four years, having allegedly fleeced orcee Carolyn Woods out of her £850,000 life savings while posing as a wealthy banker and MI6 agent, and is suspected of cheating dozens more by claiming to be a property developer, City broker, lawyer and even a gynaecologist.Cancer-stricken England fan, 63, will be held in Russia for...Tragic Alesha, six, was 'raped and murdered before her body...Share this articleHis arrest brings to an end a Europe-wide manhunt for the privately-educated swindler. Acklom, known for his love of fast cars, first-class travel and expensive hotels, is alleged to have used dozens of false identities to stay one step ahead of the authorities.At the weekend, his luck finally ran out after an international operation involving the National Crime Agency, Avon and Somerset Police and the Swiss authorities.Proceedings to extradite him to the UK are now underway and he is expected to face at least 20 charges of fraud and other offences.For his alleged victims, the news, while welcome, is bittersweet. Because it is almost impossible to overestimate the devastation they say Acklom has left in his wake.‘It has been a very long haul and my health has suffered,’ 61-year-old Miss Woods, who lives in Bath, told the Mail this week. ‘It seems every time I try to start afresh, something else happens with him and it brings the whole episode rushing back.’Meanwhile, IT specialist Christopher Frampton, 55, of Ashbourne, Derbyshire, claims his health and marriage collapsed under the strain of being fleeced out of £50,000 when, he says, the conman persuaded him to give up his lucrative corporate job for a business venture that turned out to be a scam.‘It devastated my life so much, I’m having therapy,’ he says. ‘I am cross that Acklom was living in a million-pound property in Switzerland — I lost all the money I’d saved and my family went from living comfortably to living hand-to-mouth.’          Mark Acklom (pictured) with his wife Maria Yolanda Ros Rodriguez at Ascot's Royal EnclosureEven Acklom’s own family, from whom he has been estranged for years, still bear the scars from his behaviour.His mother, Diana, told us: ‘My marriage broke up over this, and his children by his first wife don’t have anything to do with him.‘If he wanted to really run away, he should have gone to South America, like Ronnie Biggs. But I think he liked to live on the edge — he needed to have a buzz.‘I was speaking to his brother and he said: “How can he live not knowing who would be behind the next knock on the door?’’’And, make no mistake, in recent months the net had been steadily tightening around him.The current manhunt was launched in October 2016 when a European arrest warrant was issued by Avon and Somerset Police, originally focusing on allegations of fraud linked to Ms Woods.She claims that in 2012, Acklom had walked into the boutique where she worked in Tetbury, Gloucestershire, and swept her off her feet, saying he was Mark Conway, a Swiss banker.By the end of their year-long ‘romance’, Miss Woods says she had lent him every penny of her £850,000 life savings.The mother-of-two claims that she was financially ruined and on the brink of suicide when Acklom left her.When the warrant was sought, British police believed Acklom was hiding in Spain: he had a Spanish wife, Maria Yolanda Ros Rodriguez, whom he married in 2009 and with whom he had two children.But in May 2017, the hunt switched to Switzerland after he was photographed at a Geneva cafe by one of his alleged victims, who spotted him by chance.When police examined the images, they realised he was drinking coffee with a Spanish fraudster, also then on the run.The café was staked out — but Acklom never returned.Then, earlier this year, he was linked to a flat in a northern suburb of Zurich, from which it was believed he had been setting up various companies in a bid to attract investors.One business claimed to be manufacturing computer chips for black-box data recorders for cars. The company’s website suggested it had customers from the luxury car industry.Its motto is: ‘Being Defeated Is Optional.’At one point, undercover police mounted a surveillance operation on a bank following a tip-off that Acklom was planning to meet staff and business associates there, but he did not show up.At the time, Sky News revealed that Acklom still had a current passport and a Swiss residency permit in the name of Marc Long — one of several aliases he has used. The legitimate documents were obtained in 2014, shortly after Acklom fled Britain and after he had changed his name by deed poll.          As a teenager, his behaviour rapidly deteriorated from difficult to the downright dreadfulWhat we have now established is that for the past year he has been living in a stunning first-floor apartment overlooking Lake Zurich and has continued to have access to considerable sums of money.The apartment he was renting in the town of Wädenswil, 25 miles south of Zurich, would have cost him up to £2,500 a month. The children were being educated at a local private school.‘My first impression of him was that he was someone who didn’t really want to talk to people,’ said one neighbour. ‘I saw the wife and kids on the paddle board but they’d never say hello.’And Acklom himself was seemingly concerned about being recognised. He generally spoke Spanish, had grown shoulder-length hair and a bushy beard and would always wear sunglasses and a baseball cap. He looked very different, say neighbours, from his police ‘Wanted’ picture.His 47-year-old wife, meanwhile, had continued to indulge her life-long love of yoga.Since last August, she had been paying for one-to-one yoga classes, booking five sessions in advance each time. In the holidays, her ‘very sweet’ children accompanied her to the classes.She used the name Maria Longi and paid in cash — the only one of the instructor’s clients to do so.The instructor, who asked not to be named, said Maria claimed her husband managed a project concerning electronic ‘black boxes’ for cars and was ‘in the IT business’. Out of curiosity, she had searched the internet for more information, but found nothing.Although his wife is not believed to be wanted for any crime, sources close to the case have speculated whether the very existence of a wife and children — three extra people for the authorities to try to trace — may ultimately have hastened his downfall.Last autumn, police had specifically appealed for information about his wife and daughters. They said they believed the children would be attending private schools and that his wife was likely to indulge her passion for yoga.They were right on both counts.‘We have an incredibly high success rate in tracking down fugitives from British justice,’ said Ian Cruxton, head of international operations for the National Crime Agency, in the wake of the arrest.‘We do that through a host of techniques, including mobilising the ability of the public to assist us, which is why we publish the identities of these iniduals.’While celebrating the good news, those who know Acklom say they will not be happy until he is back in Britain to face justice.  Proceedings to extradite him  are now underway and he may face at least 20 charges of fraudRaised in Bromley, Kent, Mark Acklom was the eldest of four children born to a City insurance consultant. He was educated at the prestigious Dulwich Preparatory school. He then went on to board at Eastbourne College, an independent boarding and day school in East Sussex.Despite having all the advantages money could buy, from the beginning, he was a troublesome child. His mother, Diana, believes that a difficult birth may have left him with a brain injury that meant he struggled to empathise with others.‘When he was two, I bought our first puppy,’ she recalled. ‘I had just brought her home and she was sitting on the stairs. He went up and just kicked her out the way. That was the first time I thought this was odd. Most children would go up to a puppy and cuddle it.’In a bid to embrace his difference, when her son was seven, Diana placed a sign on his bedroom door reading: ‘Why be normal?’But as a teenager, his behaviour rapidly deteriorated from difficult to the downright dreadful.As an adult, Acklom made plans to become a Catholic priest then just as quickly dropped them.Next, he married a girl he met in a nightclub. His daughter and son were born shortly afterwards. But the relationship didn’t last, and Acklom walked out on his family when the children were young and never saw them again.Soon afterwards he headed to Spain, but later returned to Britain and became the director of a series of short-lived companies.In 2012, he allegedly met Miss Woods, as well as others, including Mr Frampton, and reportedly once even claimed to be a ‘close business associate’ of Formula One supremo Bernie Ecclestone.While many who met him say they suffered, Acklom and his family continued to live the high-life. Following the events of last weekend, that, however, looks set to change.Two days after his arrest, his wife, who yesterday was still in the lakeside apartment with her children, turned up as usual for her yoga session, telling the instructor that it would have to be her last.‘I don’t have the money to pay for them any more,’ she said.Quite whether she had any idea of her husband’s alleged deceptions remains to be seen. For now at least, it seems, she will no longer be enjoying the fruits of his labours.Additional reporting: Stephanie Condron

title: A shallow gassy opportunist QUENTIN LETTS Sadiq Khan
story: London Mayor Sadiq Khan (pictured) and U.S. President Donald Trump have engaged in a long-running war of words over issues such as crime and terrorismHe attended a boxing gym to improve his weedy physique and to learn how to dodge punches. Useful in politics, that is. He read law at university and became a solicitor. He had a good brain but there was also a hankering for wider acclaim. Humdrum legal work, attending to conveyancing or wills or marital disputes, will not grab headlines the way a big yellow balloon can. Human rights was where the political juice was. The eager Khan was soon developing a speciality in minority-grievance cases.He became a partner in his firm by his mid-30s, dabbled in local politics and increasingly styled himself the representative of high-profile victims of what he might in those days have called ‘the establishment system’. From there, in those days of early Blairism, it was a comparatively easy step to become Labour MP for Tooting in 2005.At first he was impressive: his energy palpable as he caught the Speaker’s eye. His voice had an urgency. He worked his fringe into a little quiff with hair gel. He was a boxy-shouldered, bustling figure and earned some respect for the way he ignored the New Labour Whips and – apparently acting from the highest principles – opposed Tony Blair’s plans to lock up terror suspects for 90 days without charge. He also criticised Blair for the invasion of Iraq.But then ambition again infected his bones. After Gordon Brown replaced Blair as Prime Minister, the Whips sidled up to the man who had so recently rebelled against them.Did he fancy joining their crew? A job in the Government! Mr Khan almost bit their hands off and became a Whip (ie an enforcer among Labour MPs). Soon he was badgering other MPs to vote for detention periods of 42 days without charge. How easily had those once precious principles been blunted.'The biggest insult to a sitting US president ever': Nigel...Meet the men behind the anti-Trump protests: The wealthy...Share this articleSince then this oddly insubstantial figure has floated upwards – and away from his working-class roots – on a series of felicitous thermals. Most politicians are egomaniacs but this one takes it to new, almost comical extremes (there is a glorious photograph of him striking a butch pose and placing his hand on some railings which had a ‘WET PAINT’ sign on them).Most politicians break or bend their word but this one does it with bells on. Most politicians are opportunists but Sadiq Khan has made short-term posturing so much his speciality, he would win the gold medal for it at any Interstellar Olympics. Take his non-gender-specific traffic lights. When ‘trans rights’ were the big thing a couple of years ago, someone suggested – for all I know in jest – that it was a denial of trans people’s rights that pedestrian signals at road crossings only showed a little green or red man.And so the newly-elected Mayor Khan ordained that such lights, at public cost and to widespread mockery, should be altered so that the signals now show politically-correct diagrams rather than a little chap.Take his indignant demand for a national bank holiday for Prince Harry’s wedding (er, it was held on a Saturday). One day it was a headline, the next day, amid embarrassed coughing, it could be filed under ‘Y’ for ‘yesterday’s news’.Or his feckless declaration that new homes in central London should not be allocated parking spaces because residents should use public transport – the same public transport whose fees he has allowed to rise – and save the planet by reducing their carbon footprint. How were homeowners meant to struggle home with the weekly supermarket shopping?          An inflatable balloon depicting Donald Trump as a baby wearing a nappy, which will fly over London when the President visits on July 13, with one of its creators Leo MurrayMr Khan’s eco-lecturing did not stop him making a much-trumpeted vanity trip to Pakistan and India where one of his great photo-opportunities coincided with a terrible smog in Delhi and he was almost completely invisible posing for photographs in the pea-souper. The trip was depicted as a ‘coming home’ for him, yet when he was asked about that, he said, ‘I’m from London, mate’. Was he playing it both ways, tacking to the minority-ethnic vote while at the same time asserting his London-born credentials? Perish the thought!But that, alas, is the nature of this shallow, self-serving figure, a man many Labour MPs have still not forgiven for encouraging Ed Miliband to stand against his brother David for the Labour leadership in 2010, a disastrous misjudgement which led to the party being taken over by the extremists of Momentum.Mr Khan may not worry much about that. After all, he himself is safely ensconced as London mayor, having beaten a weak challenge from the Tory candidate Zac Goldsmith in 2016. I’m all right Jack!Likewise, he will be thinking himself jolly clever this weekend as the country prepares for Mr Trump’s visit. He has got one over the most powerful man in the world!In London, it is claimed, Donald Trump is widely disliked. He is certainly opposed by the metropolitan elite, who have never forgiven him for beating their heroine Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election.You wonder, however, what they think of Trump on those building sites and boxing gyms where the young Sadiq Khan spent his time.I suspect they have a rather higher opinion of the US President as someone who stands up for the working classes and who speaks their language.Trump is certainly a better communicator than arid, charmless Khan. The best political communicators speak from the heart. It is when politicians strike false poses, with words written for them by strategists and advisers, that they fail to convince.And the sorry fact is that since he became London mayor, Mr Khan has struggled to say anything interesting or radical.When the creators of the ‘Baby Trump’ balloon first told London’s City Hall about their stunt, they met with little reaction. But then, suddenly, the project was given the mayor’s blessing.Did Mr Khan’s Press handlers suddenly get wind of the wheeze and spot its potential for a few headlines that might move the public’s attention away from his dreadful record on crime prevention?Mr Khan’s decision to make a political thing of this balloon lark will no doubt win the acclaim of the Twittersphere. But the City of London’s banks and finance houses depend greatly on American custom and goodwill. Donald Trump is a notoriously touchy president. As a nation we need to persuade him to give post-Brexit Britain a trade deal.The balloon stunt will gain Mr Khan oodles of publicity. But what will it do for the reputation of a City, and our country, which needs to earn the goodwill of the White House?Would a serious mayor, a proper, substantial, internationally-minded leader of our capital city, in touch with his real constituents rather than fringe protesters, not have put such considerations above his own childish posturing?As for that Baby Trump inflatable, we must earnestly hope it is not peppered by someone with a long-distance rifle. Pop goes the weasel Khan’s silly stunt. One can but hope.

title: Alan Titchmarsh says water companies stop blaming gardeners
story: Aerial images highlight the effect the heatwave is having on Britain's green and pleasant land as the parched earth turns an arid yellow amid scorching temperatures and little rainfall    With the heatwave set to last, suppliers are warning their customers to use less water or face a banBut Titchmarsh, 69, hit out at the warnings, saying that water firms waste so much in leaks themselves.Three billion litres of water simply drains away every day, according to regulator Ofwat. Titchmarsh told Horticulture Week magazine: ‘A hosepipe ban would be galling when so much water is not properly managed and leaks. And when they blame gardeners, that really is galling.’STEAM trains! London tube passengers suffer in unbearable...The DESERT Isles! Britain's green and pleasant land turned...Share this articleThe TV presenter did, however, urge gardeners not to water their lawns and wait until it rains.He has previously claimed that gardeners are actually among the most responsible water users and complained about water firms charging customers ‘a fortune’.          Alan Titchmarsh criticised water companies for blaming gardeners for shortages as fears rise of a summer of hosepipe bans          Drought fears have been raised again as parts of the upper River Teme in Herefordshire have been reduced to mere puddles

title: Two cats litter born without legs
story: Frog the tabby cat and his brother Newt were both born 10 weeks ago without rear legs          Despite their lack of rear legs, both cats are perfectly able to walk around without any pain          Animal rescuers said the kittens received their names as there are frogs and newts at the centreAnd they are being well cared for at the Rescue Me Animal Sanctuary in Liverpool, which took them in ten days ago after the owner advertised them on social media.The sanctuary is unaware of any other two-legged cats born in the UK.Thought to be ten weeks old, they got their names because there are lots of frogs and newts at the rescue centre.Because they are from the same litter, it is believed inbreeding may have led to them being born without their back legs. Sanctuary founder Steph Taylor said: ‘It doesn’t seem to affect them at all, they are scratching up scratch posts. They even manage to jump down from levels as well. They are doing really well.’Frog and Newt will be kept in long-term care to assess their progress. Because they are thriving, there are no plans to fit them with wheels, which can happen with animals that lose their legs.The sanctuary looks after some 500 animals a year, with each cat or kitten rescued costing it around £60. To offer support or make a donation, visit @RescueMeAnimal on Facebook.

We have five presenters, they all have different strengths.’Laughing, she added: ‘I think, on the whole, Mishal and Martha might be slightly better on fashion.’'Who are you to tell me how to do things?' Tennis bad boy...Peaky Blinders street in Liverpool opens to new residents...Share this articleShe described the team as a whole as ‘first rate’. title: Wilander backing Edmund upset Djokovic
story: Kyle Edmund won the first set against Novak Djokovic in his third round Wimbeldon clash, starting minutes after England won a place in the World Cup semi finals          The Yorkshire player didn't let them down as he won a thrilling first set 6-4, showing he is a serious threat to the former world number oneThose who have tickets for Saturday's tennis were issued with pink and blue re-entry wristbands so they could run back inside once the football action was over.The Yorkshire player didn't let them down as he won a thrilling first set 6-4, showing he is a serious threat to the former world number one. Three Lions ROAR! England fans turn the streets of Samara...Up to 10,000 tickets go unsold for the England vs Sweden...Share this articleBefore the England match started there were chants of 'get the tennis off' as fans waited eagerly for the football to be put on the big screens.Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, has seats on Court One but has left to watch the football. 'It's the most people who have left Wimbledon on middle Saturday between 1pm and 2pm. There's more people leaving than going in,' he said.          Scores of fans apparently left Wimbledon this afternoon in order to make it to a pub in time to watch England play against Sweden in the World Cup quarter final          This fan was streaming the England vs Sweden World Cup quarter final while sat at Centre Court to watch Rafael Nadal in action          Fans left the tennis to go and watch the football in the nearby Rose and Crown pub in Wimbledon village, they can be seen reacting to a near miss          Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, has seats on Court One but has left to watch the football, he said there were more people leaving the tennis than arriving          Some fans were clearly more concerned with the football than the tennis and could be seen cheekily watching on their phones          Another fan proudly showed how they were streaming the World Cup quarter final on their phone rather than pay attention to what was happening on the court          This fan could be seen paying absolutely no attention to the tennis as he watched the World Cup match on his tablet on court number one          Even the legends and officials seemed to be getting involved as Rod Laver, Billy Jean King and Phillip Brook, AELTC Chairman, all appeared to be distracted          Sweden fans at Wimbledon look disappointed as they check the score and realise that their team are losing to England after Harrey Maguire scored          This England fan could be seen screaming in joy at Wimbledon as she realised that they had scored against Sweden in the World Cup          Hundreds of fans piled onto Murray Mound today as they waited for Kyle Edmund to face three time Wimbledon champion Novak Djokovic - although some seemed more concerned with the football          Although the fans had come to watch the tennis, they could be seen unfurling England flags and wearing replica shirts with the names of some of the players          As fans flocked to watch the tennis, many were dressed in England football shirts ahead of the big World Cup tie later this afternoon          British tennis number one Kyle Edmund, pictured, is facing a major task today but took the the time out to throw his support behind the England football time          It is set to be another scorching hot day today at Wimbledon, with maximum temperatures reaching 31C (88F), according to forecastersBefore that, fans could be seen knocking back pints and basking in the gorgeous sunshine as they got ready to cheer on Kyle Edmund, the last remaining British singles player, at Wimbledon.Sir Bobby Charlton was also spotted signing autographs and joining in on the fun.The World Cup winner seemed to be relaxed ahead a big day of sport for England with the World Cup quarter-final and Kyle Edmund set to take on three-time Wimbledon champion Novak Djokovic.           Although it was mainly England fans at Wimbledon, Amanda Strang (pictured) is a Sweden fan who also looks set to enjoy Wimbledon ahead of the match          The influence of the football was widespread with a number of fans dressed in England shirts and looking in high spiritsSir Bobby  was among those in the royal box on  Saturday.He was joined by sporting stars including Sir Mo Farah, boxer David Haye, Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill and former cricketer Andrew Strauss, on another scorching day at Wimbledon.The All England Lawn Tennis Club (AELTC) announced on Friday that Edmund will play third on Centre Court, with the scheduling likely to avoid a clash between the tennis and football.Haye admitted he would be one of those trying to juggle the two sporting events.          Some England fans found a novel way to express their support for their country as they wore hats with a passionate Gareth Southgate on them           Sir Bobby Charlton was spotted visiting Wimbledon today despite the England vs Sweden World Cup quarter-final being just hours away          England and Liverpool footballer Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain missed the World Cup through injury and he was also at Wimbledon          The former World Cup winner and England legend joined a host of other sporting personalities to watch the tennis, with British number one Kyle Edmund set to take on Novak Djokovic          Fans could be seen enjoying the sun as they relaxed ahead of the big tennis clash which sees Edmund face Djokovic as Britain's last hope'I'll try, I dunno how,' he told the Press Association.'We're going to do it, we're going to do it.'Tennis star Heather Watson, who is not due to play on Saturday, also appeared preoccupied by the football.She tweeted on Saturday: 'FOOTBALL IS COMING HOME.'          There may be some ision in the Edmund camp with his coach, Fredrik Rosengren, being Swedish and his match starting an hour or so after the England tie          With Edmund and England's football team both in action today, fans are set for an exciting day of action and seemed to be well-setHowever Sir Cliff Richard, a regular at Wimbledon, said he would not be focusing on England's quarter-final.'I'm watching tennis. I'm here for tennis,' he said as he arrived.'I'll get the results later. I hope they do well.'            Former England footballer Bobby Charlton and his wife Norma take their seat in the Royal box on Centre Court before watching Spain's Rafael Nadal play against Australia's Alex De MinaurEdmund will head to Centre Court with his coach Fredrik Rosengren urging him to enjoy the moment in what is sure to be a difficult match. Edmund was spotted with an England flag yesterday, as he threw his support behind the England football team ahead of their crunch World Cup contest.And there may be some ision in the Edmund camp with Fredrik Rosengren being Swedish.          Jessica Ennis-Hill was another of the sporting royalty to take their place in the centre court Royal box at Wimbledon today, as they await Kyle Edmund's match          Former England cricket captain  Andrew Strauss was also in the royal box on centre court ahead of Edmund's crunch matchOlympic gold medal boxer Nicola Adams, who will also be in the royal box, said: 'I'll be focusing on the tennis - and hopefully I'll get the updates later.'Asked if she had a message for Edmund and the England team, Adams said: 'Good luck, and I hope they do really well, they've done really good so far.'Edmund hopes both he and the national side will triumph in their knockout matches.          Olympic gold medalist swimmer Adam Peaty looked dapper in a white suit as he took his place in the Wimbledon Royal box today The 23-year-old, who previously said he hoped to watch some of the England game, may be able to catch a glimpse if it does not interfere with his pre-match routine.The first clash on Centre Court will begin at 1pm, while England's game will kick off at 3pm.Since 2005, the average time for the first point of the third Centre Court match on middle Saturday has been 6.21pm, IBM analysis shows.          Former Rugby legend Dr J P R Williams (pictured) is also on the royal box on centre court today,  on day six of the WimbledonThe earliest start time for the third match was 3.56pm, but on just two out of 11 occasions did it start before 4.30pm.Edmund seems raring for another appearance on Wimbledon's premier court.He tweeted on Friday: 'Can't wait to get my teeth into Centre court again tomorrow.'           Legendary commentator Barry Davies also turned up to watch Edmund, with the 23-year-old British number one scheduled to be on court at 4.15pmIt is set to be a hot day at Wimbledon, with maximum temperatures of 31C (88F), forecasters said.Spectators will need to slap on the sun cream with UV levels likely to become very high by mid-afternoon.And the football influence was clear at Wimbledon as several fans wore England shirts and brandished flags ahead of the  tie.Some could be seen enjoying a pint and basking in the sunshine as they flocked to Murray Mound ahead of the Edmund-Djokovic clash. Seven-time Grand Slam winner Mats Wilander is backing him to upset Djokovic.Wilander believes the 23-year-old is ready to take the scalp, saying: 'He goes in as the underdog if you look at what they've done, but not necessarily right at this moment in their careers I don't think.          Judy Murray and Strictly dancer Neil Jones were also in attendance ahead of the match between Edmund and Djokovic - which is set to kick off at 4.15pm          Former boxing world champion joined Sir Bobby Charlton as one of the sporting personalities visiting Wimbledon ahead of Edmund's match          Despite the huge football match set to start at 3pm, thousands of fans turned up for the sixth day of action at Wimbledon today          Former England Rugby captain Chris Robshaw and singer Camilla Kerslake were also among the stars attending day six of Wimbledon'Obviously Djokovic is playing better and better but he still hasn't won a tournament (this season) and he's lost quite a few really close matches thathave meant a lot. It's obvious he's not playing as well on the big points.'I think you have to go in and not overplay just because Djokovic has 12 majors. Djokovic is playing better because grass I think suits his game at themoment, grass usually suits your game better when you're less confident because it's about staying alive in the points.'Kyle will have time to maybe manoeuvre Djokovic around with his forehand. Obviously he has to serve well. The longer the rallies, the longer the match, the better the chances probably for Djokovic. Not that Kyle gets tired, butexperience at some point plays a role.'But he's won his first match on Centre Court, that's huge. I think Kyle isready.'Edmund has so far appeared utterly unfazed about carrying the weight of home expectation at Wimbledon for the first time, and can take confidence from his last meeting with Djokovic in Madrid in May, when he claimed his first win in four against the Serbian.  Coach Fredrik Rosengren wants Kyle Edmund to enjoy facing Novak Djokovic ahead of their contest on Centre Court today          Former Tennis players Billie Jean King and Rod Laver (pictured) were among the stars in the royal box on centre court todayRosengren said: 'To play one of the best guys ever in tennis on the mostfamous court on home soil, in my opinion it can't be bigger than that.'That is something he has to be very proud of. He has achieved so much so it's great, but at the same time you have to find a balance of not being too excited,you go in and try to play to win. He is in unbelievably good shape mentally. We talk a lot about that, to enjoy it. Sometimes we all forget the joy of playing.'The shocks continued in the women's draw on Friday, with last year's runner-up Venus Williams and her American compatriot Madison Keys joining the exodus of top-10 seeds.Only Simona Halep and Karolina Pliskova remain, but Serena Williams is looming large after beating Kristina Mladenovic to reach round four. Roger Federer made it 29 consecutive sets won at Wimbledon as the men's draw remained much more predictable so far.          Large groups of spectators could be seen queuing up in the sunshine ahead of an exciting day's play at Wimbledon (pictured)          With Andy Murray ruled out of Wimbledon and all the British women now eliminated, Kyle Edmund is now Britain's last hope at the tournament

title: Streaming delay make England fans using phones irate waiting overdue flight
story: This morning, Neil Hall, the product team lead for BBC Sport warned users watching on mobile devices may face a 20 second delay compared to watching on BBC One. Hundreds of people took to Twitter to complain their stream was down in the last five minutes of the game. Neil Hall, the product team lead for BBC Sport said the delay was 'one of the big issues in emerging technology'. Three Lions ROAR! England fans turn the streets of Samara...'We'll make the nation proud': England captain Harry Kane...Share this articleA twenty second delay is significant. For example, in England's last match those watching on live TV would be celebrating victory while for those watching on a live stream, Eric Dier would still be approaching the goal.The number of people watching online and on mobile devices is on the rise, particularly with millennials and Generation Z viewers. Ahead of today's match, 43.5million people have already watched a live stream on the BBC - more than double that watched all games online during Euro 2016.            Up to 30 million people are expected to tune into today's game to see the Three Lions take on Sweden in the quarter finals of the World CupAround 45 percent of streams are through mobiles, a shift from years ago when people were streaming through fast broadband, Neil Hall told the Guardian.  People getting married today have been told to be vigilant of guests watching the game, as have theatre performers and even Wimbledon players.The World Cup will not be shown at Wimbledon, after images of Centre Court being deserted as fans even flocked from the match where Jenena Ostapenko was playing Katy Dunneto to catch the Three Lions play. MailOnline has contacted BBC for comment.           In England's last match those watching on live TV would be celebrating victory while for those watching on a live stream, Eric Dier would still be approaching the goal to take his winning penalty          Millions of people will tune in to watch the game live and in public spaces across the countryLivestream of England match will have 20-second delay, says BBC | Football | The Guardian

title: DROUGHT order Reservoirs run dry 46 day dry spell
story: The dried up bed of the United Utilities owned Wayoh Reservoir in the village of Edgworth, Bolton, Lancashire. Three million homes could be hit with a hosepipe ban if demand does not fall in the north-west of England          Dustbowl: Wayoh Reservoir looks more like a desert now as Britain sizzles in a scorching heatwave that has seen very little rainfall in the past three weeks           United Utilities, which serves the North-West of England, says it will have no choice but to impose the ban if water demand does not fall soon          A ban would prohibit householders from watering their gardens with hosepipes and sprinklers, as well as cleaning cars and filling garden ponds and children’s paddling pools          A global map of temperatures from July 7 2018 showing the above average heat which is affecting the northern hemisphereUnited Utilities, which serves the North-West of England, says it will have no choice but to impose the ban if water demand does not fall soon.The region has not had rain for three weeks, leading to falling reservoir levels.A ban would prohibit householders from watering their gardens with hosepipes and sprinklers, as well as cleaning cars and filling garden ponds and children’s paddling pools.The highest temperature of the day yesterday was 86F (30C), recorded at Gosport, Hampshire, at 1.37pm. Today could be even hotter, with the mercury potentially reaching 91F (33C) in the South East.The extreme weather conditions have been taking their toll on roads, with melting tarmac leading to a number of incidents around the country. In one, the wheels of a bin lorry dropped suddenly as the road gave way beneath it during a round in Newbury, Berkshire.The crew of the West Berkshire Council bin lorry were thrown forward without warning as the truck lurched to a halt on Thursday.    Natasha Jenkins makes the most of the sunny hot weather on Aberavon Beach in south Wales          Spectators shelter in the queue at the start of day six of the Wimbledon Championships at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, Wimbledon          Spectators relax in the queue at the start of day six of the Wimbledon Championships at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, Wimbledon          The sun rises over Keyhaven Harbour in The New Forest Seasonal Weather, Keyhaven Harbour this morning           A match gets underway at Calmore Cricket Club, Hampshire. The highest temperature of the day yesterday was 86F (30C), recorded at Gosport, Hampshire, at 1.37pm. Pictured: The scene at Dovestone Reservoir in Saddleworth, Greater Manchester yesterday          Spectators planning to watch the Henley Royal Regatta had been hoping to take advantage of the dry weather to have barbecues. Pictured: The scene at Dovestone Reservoir in Saddleworth, Greater Manchester yesterday          Taking in the whole of the UK, the hottest was 91F (33C) in Porthmadog, Wales, on June 28. Pictured: The scene at Dovestone Reservoir in Saddleworth, Greater Manchester yesterday          Two women enjoy a day by the water at Dovestone Reservoir in Saddleworth, Greater Manchester, yesterday But councillors who fear they could pose a fire risk have banned them from one of the most popular spots to view the rowing races, Marsh Meadows.The ban could remain in place until September because of the dry condition of the grass.Councillor Kellie Hinton said: ‘We have taken this action for health and safety reasons. title: England fans queue outside pubs FIVE hours watch World Cup clash Sweden
story: These fans in London could be seen cheering wildly and throwing beer around as Dele Alli added a second goal for England against Sweden    England fans in Croydon's Boxpark go wild as Deli Alli heads home second goal after Harry Maguire headed in the first           England fans in Bristol's Ashton Gate Stadium hurl beer in the air the moment Deli Alli scores England's second goal           The moment England fans in  Flat Iron Square, London believe World Cup glory could be theirs as Three Lions scored again          Now it's TWO! England fans scream with joy as Deli Alli heads home Three Lions' second goal against Sweden in World CupAt the Rose and Crown pub in Wimbledon village, scores of fans have gathered for the England game, including many who have left Wimbledon.Those who have tickets for Saturday's tennis have been issued with pink and blue re-entry wristbands.There were chants of 'get the tennis off' as fans waited eagerly for the football to be put on the big screens.Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, has seats on Court One but has left to watch the football.He said: 'It's the most people who have left Wimbledon on middle Saturday between 1pm and 2pm.'He added: 'There's more people leaving than going in.'    Goal! Beer spills in the air as England fans celebrating Maguire's goal throw their arms up in joy          Celebrations! Fans celebrate after Harry Maguire nets England's first goal, putting them ahead of Sweden          Beer rockets into the skies in Bristol as Three Lions fans cheer with pride after Harry Maguire scores first goal in Sweden clash    YEESSSSS! Three Lions fans in London explode with joy as Harry Maguire heads home England's first goal in quarter-finalFans in Cheshire dressed up as England manager Gareth Southgate wearing his trademark navy suit and waistcoast.The group who headed out in Nantwich to catch the game wore light blue shirts and a stripy ties, and even wore with paper masks with the manager's face on.Last week, M&ampS revealed that sales of waistcoats, which Southgate has worn for every one of his four touchline appearances at England's matches, have rocketed by 35 per cent since the tournament began.          Back of the net! Fans celebrate Harry Maguire's goal at Flat Iron Square in south London          England fans celebrate the Three Lions first goal as they take on Sweden in the World Cup quarter finals at Ashton Gate          England fans celebrate the first goal from Harry Maguire at the Rose &amp Crown pub, in Wimbledon, south London          One - nil! Fans at a big screen in London celebrate as Harry Maguire scores a bullet header          It's coming home! Fans at Flat Iron Square in south London cheer on Harry Kane and the boys as England take on Sweden          Fans react to a near miss from England whilst watching coverage of the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England at the Rose &amp Crown pub, in Wimbledon           Fans - many that have left the tennis in Wimbledon - react to a near miss from captain Harry Kane           A couple appear distracted by a device after England have kick off in a World Cup quarter final while Rafael Nadal and Alex De Minaur plays on Centre Court Wimbledon Tennis Championships          England fans go wild as they see Harry Maguire head home ball while watching on giant screen at London's Wireless festival             A football fan streams the World Cup Quarter Final action on a phone during the Rafael Nadal match on Centre Court Wimbledon Tennis Championships          England fans climb on one another shoulders to watch the match on the big screen at Flat Iron Square in Borough, London          Fans in Flat Iron Square get ready for the big game as they grab beers and wear Three Lions shirtsUp to 10,000 tickets go unsold for the England vs Sweden...England changes the channel: British hopeful Kyle Edmund...Not just their big day! Couples prepare to tie the knot as...Share this article    Fans ready to watch the coverage of the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England at the Rose &amp Crown pub, in Wimbledon - many who have left the tennis to catch the Three Lions play          England fans arrive at Flat Iron Square in Borough in south London to catch the game          England fans arrive to watch the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England at Luna Beach Cinema, Brighton          Beer we go! England fans cheer as they watch England v Sweden quarter-final clash in Bristol          England fans cheer on the Three Lions at Wimbledon where Britain's Kyle Edmund is set to play this Super Saturday          Three Lions roar: England fans show their support for Harry Kane's boys during day out at Wimbledon           Kiss of St George: England fans plant a smooch on Three Lions fan with red-and-white painted head at Croydon's Boxpark           England football fans in Croydon's Boxpark sing and cheer before the start of the England v Sweden quarter final match          England fans gather along the canalside in Birmingham ahead of the national team's quarter final game against Sweden          Three England fans don replica shirts to drink pints ahead of the Three Lions game with Sweden this afternoon  Fans excitedly pose draped in a cross of St George and England shirts...while one fan created a shirt of his own drawing the Three Lions on          Fans where hats and drink pints as they prepare to see the Three Lions take on the Swedish team          Fans in Bristol drape themselves in the pub of St. George and raise a glass to the Three Lions as they prepare to watch England take on Sweden          These supporters have been queuing up since 10am this morning to get into The George pub in London Bridge to watch today's tie          The fervent fans baked in sizzling 91.5F (33C) heat as they waited to secure a space inside the traditional English pub          A line wraps around the block outside of a pub in Clapham shortly before 12pm today - almost four hours before the match kicks off          England fans show support for Gareth Southgate and his team as they head out to watch the match in Nantwich dressed in Southgate trademark navy suit          All together now! Fans dress up as the England manager as they head to watch the Three Lions take on SwedenEngland's victories so far in Russia have sparked scenes of wild celebration here and the atmosphere today will be electric - especially if they progress.The Three Lions are attempting to reach their first World Cup semi-final for 28 years.  Elsewhere, crowds have flocked to outdoor big screens in cities including London, Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, Bristol, Exeter and Leeds to make the most of the beautiful weather while watching the game.  To help keep cool - or steady the nerves - 38 million pints of beer are set to be drunk by fans as the latest chapter in captain Harry Kane and the team's Russian adventure triggers a £190million big-game drinks and food spree. Some 18 million pints are expected to be downed in pubs - 7 million more than usual - with pub takings soaring to £100 million as a predicted 3.5 million fans pack the country's 40,000 pubs to watch the match.At home, 20m pints are expected to be drunk today costing around £22m, the British Beer and Pub Association (BBPA) said. Food spending on the match will add up to another £30m in pubs and £40m at home.  However, not all of the UK was getting behind the Three Lions.Swedes and Scots packed into Akva, a Swedish bar in Edinburgh's west end, to watch the match.There was Swedish bunting and flags, with many fans wearing the side's yellow strip.A faulty connection added to the tension outside in the beer garden, where supporters groaned as the large screen showing the game repeatedly cut off.            Fans hold up 'It's Coming Home' signs and wear Three Lions shirts at Nass Festival in Bath          England fans get ready for the game ahead of the England Match at the Nass Festival in Bath          There was a massive queue outside of The Original Oak in Headingley, Leeds, this morning. Around 32 million viewers are expected to tune in to BBC1 to watch Gareth Southgate's men          Fans queue outside Water Poet in Liverpool Street, central London, this morning to watch England attempt to reach their first World Cup semi-final for 28 years           Dedicated supporters waited for hours outside other pubs in London Bridge. 38 million pints of beer are set to be drunk by fans          They could be seen singing and cheering as they celebrated while at the San Fermin festival in Pamplona, Spain          Fans from around the world were seen celebrating Harry Maguire's goal, such as these fans at the San Fermin festival in Spain  Eerie photos reveal empty streets, motorways with no traffic and a soulless Bluewater shopping centre during Three Lions clashWith so many watching the match, the nation will come to a halt with roads, high streets and train stations likely to be empty during the quarter-final, which will be shown live on BBC1.The RAC said it expects 'the quietest Saturday afternoon of the year, with deserted roads.'Shopping centres such as London's Oxford Street - one of the world's most famous shopping destinations - are also expected to be quieter than they typically would be on a Saturday afternoonElsewhere, shops and streets were deserted as everyone headed to the nearest screen to catch the game.Bluewater in Kent, one of the country's biggest shopping centres was like a ghost town.The usually bustling indoor shopping street saw barely anyone frequent the big name high street chains such as Waterstones, House of Fraser and Urban Outfitters.          An empty bluewater shopping centre minutes before England kicked off their quarter final match with Sweden          Fans clear out of shopping centres and head to the pub to watch England play          Bluewater shopping centre was exceedingly quiet as fans disappeared away from shops to watch the quarter finals          A deserted Tyne Bridge at 3pm today as fans head to the pub to watch England take on Sweden in the biggest Three Lions match in a decade

title: Couples prepare tie knot England face Sweden World Cup
story: Football comes first! One wedding guest joked their priority was the Three Lions, not he nuptials          Keelan Hall and Kerry Warren arrived at their reception at Carlton Park Hotel in Rotherham just in time for kick off before settling down with their guests to watch the game          Initially Kerry 'wasn't impressed' with Keelan's idea but changed her mind after England's win over Colombia and told friends on Facebook: 'Your most probably going to ruin my wedding day but... Come on England!!!!!'          The new Mr and Mrs Hall were cheered by friends and family just before the game started before the wedding party settle down for food, drink and footballNadine Hanlon, 43, and Lee Hanlon, 40, from Rutland, will be renewed their vows today after 21 years of marriage.While Lee prefers rugby, Nadine, an American who met her husband in the British Army, describes herself and her two sons as 'major' fans of the beautiful game and says all three have football-related tattoos on their legs.  They are celebrating in Doncaster and results in recent days saw the last-minute addition of a big screen so attendees could watch along during the wedding breakfast.'I love the man but no way am I missing the game!' Nadine said.          Football mad bride Nadine Hanlon reacts after England score in the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England          Nadine Hanlon shows off her Arsenal tattoo as she watches coverage of the FIFA World Cup 2018'We sort of planned around it. The church service is at 1300 and then the wedding breakfast is at 1500, big screen next to the top table.'She added: 'My husband is in the military and we married on July 4, 1997, every time we tried to renew our vows he ended up deploying on active duty, so we managed to book this year, sadly he will be deploying again in a couple of months.''Quickly say I do, she does, couple of pics, then jump in the wedding car'          The bride and her groom Lee Hanlon watched the game with their guests before their wedding breakfast at the Regent Hotel in Doncaster          'I love the man but no way am I missing the game!' Nadine said, as they showed the big game ahead of their wedding in Doncaster          While Lee prefers rugby, Nadine, an American who met her husband in the British Army, describes herself and her two sons as 'major' fans of the beautiful game and says all three have football-related tattoos on their legsKeelan Hall and Kerry Warren arrived at their reception at Carlton Park Hotel in Rotherham just in time for kick off before settling down with their guests to watch the game.Initially Kerry 'wasn't impressed' with Keelan's idea but changed her mind after England's win over Colombia and told friends on Facebook: 'Your most probably going to ruin my wedding day but... Come on England!!!!!'  Up to 32million people are expected to watch the game and couples marrying this weekend are changing their plans and installing TVs at their venues so guests don't cancel or spend the day on their phones or tablets.But the guests and wedding party arrived late to the venue, and missed the first goal.          A fan looks at the screen in awe at the wedding of Kerry and Keelan Hall          Fans tuck into drinks and dinner at the wedding reception - which is showing the England game in the background          GOAL! Fans at the wedding of Mr and Mrs Hall celebrate the goal as England go 2-0 aheadSpeaking to Good Morning Britain Mr Hall said: 'There has been a lot of debate over the last two weeks or so. Originally we weren't going to play it because Kerry wasn't really impressed by the idea.'But after the England game on Tuesday she has really bought into it and came around to it and made the decision yesterday morning'. The new Mr and Mrs Hall were cheered by friends and family just before the game starts before the wedding party settle down for food, drink and football.Mr Hall said: 'We arrive here at 2.50pm so the guests will be seated and we'll be toasted in ready for kick off. It'll be played throughout the meal. We're going to embrace the atmosphere and hopefully it will make it a better day'.           No need for speeches! The bride and groom put on the game as fans watch Maguire score          Keelan Hall and Kerry Warren, pictured with their son, will show the England to guests at their wedding tomorrow  after the bride-to-beFans in Croydon cheer massively as England scores 2nd goalSearch teams seek alternative exits for trapped soccer teamDawn Sturgess captured on CCTV hours before 'Novichok' poisoningEngland fans at Silverstone celebrate first goal against SwedenRevellers enjoy the 2018 Pride festivities in central London'Football is NOT coming home': Noel Gallagher irritates fans at concertDash cam captures carpark crash that has ided the internetCouple say they've decided to show the World Cup at their weddingEngland fans cheers as Maguire opens the scoring for EnglandRescue mission: new footage surfaces from depths of flooded Thai caveSerena Williams tends to daughter before going to win at Wimbledon    Initially Kerry 'wasn't impressed' with Keelan's idea (pictured together) but changed her mind after England's win over ColombiaNotts County season-ticket holder Carl Younger, 54, didn't expect England to reach the quarter-finals when he set the date to tie the knot with Angela Laud, 53.Now family and friends are set to miss out on the big game with his son Josh, who is the best man on the day, asking: 'How can you do this to me, Dad?!'Angela, who is a support worker for people with disabilities, said: 'We picked this date because we met on July 8 and we thought Saturday would be better than Sunday.          Notts County season-ticket holder Carl Younger, 54, didn't expect England to reach the quarter-finals when he set the date to tie the knot with Angela Laud, 53          The couple, from Sneinton, Nottinghamshire, are set to tie the knot at Bridgford Hall registry office at 3pm, before the wedding reception at Copper in West Bridgford'We did not think about the World Cup and we never thought England would get through.'I feel guilty because I have upset so many people. The vows will only take about 45 minutes so we are hoping they will be able to watch the second half.'Carl's sister's children are not happy and my son is not happy and Carl's son who is a big football fan said - 'how can you do this to me, dad?''My nephews are also massive football fans. It might be ladies only at this wedding the way it is going. I am just hoping that the first half will be boring so they don't miss anything.'Newlyweds are told with just three days' notice they can't...Neymar's ROLLING home! Football fans worldwide fail to hide...'Football's Coming Home!': Prince William speaks for the...It's coming homeware! Pranksters raid IKEA and label...Share this articleThe couple, from Sneinton, Nottinghamshire, tied the knot at Bridgford Hall registry office at 3pm, before the wedding reception at Copper in West Bridgford.Builder Carl said: 'The World Cup did not cross my mind at the time. I did not miss a Notts County game last season so when it comes to football I will watch anything.'I have watched nearly every game of the World Cup. When we beat Colombia I was over the moon and then I looked at the list and saw we were playing Sweden on Saturday.'I really hope that we win and this might be a good luck charm for England that we are getting married at the same time.'          Friends Shaun Cureton and James Cureton with Angela Laud and Carl YoungerRegistrar Hazel Tait, who married the happy couple on Saturday, said: 'Angela and Carl are trying to put measures in place for themselves and their guests.'In terms of the registrar we will be working and we have a lot of weddings that day.'We have 20 weddings across the southern part of the county alone. We are hoping that the weddings at the end of the day will be able to fill us in on how we are doing.'However, another couple have rearranged their wedding.  Groom Nick Hawley has even postponed the wedding reception until after 5.30pm in case the knockout game goes to penalties.          Sue Potter and Nick Hawley pictured outside the Picnic Stop, which Sue runs          As soon as Eric Dier scored the winning penalty for England in Tuesday night's cliffhanger with Columbia, bride, Sue Potter resigned herself to having all her wedding plans thrown up in the airAs soon as Eric Dier scored the winning penalty for England in Tuesday night's cliffhanger with Columbia, bride, Sue Potter resigned herself to having all her wedding plans thrown up in the air.Football-mad Nick was almost instantly on the phone to wedding planners to rearrange the times of their wedding and reception.Sue said: 'England had better bring the World Cup home after all the sacrifice I have made on my big day.'I knew as soon as they won that it was all going to get changed.'Up until then it was all going swimmingly.'I knew it wouldn't go to plan because on Tuesday, as well as the game, one of the bridesmaids dresses went missing and our dog sitter had to cancel. So it was going to happen whatever.'          Groom Nick Hawley has even postponed the wedding reception until after 5.30pm in case the knockout game goes to penaltiesSue, 43, the owner of The Picnic Stop sandwich bar and cafe in Cleethorpes said: 'Nick got on to the lady at the hotel and brought it forward to 2.30pm and then got the reception and speeches put back to 5.30pm.'Despite the upheaval, Sue said she was excited about tying the knot with Nick after being together 18 years.'We decided to do it this year. Nick wanted a massive wedding but I have persuaded him to keep it small and there are 29 of us going to Gretna Green,' said Sue.'I love him because of his weird sense of humour and he makes me laugh everyday and he is kind and very sociable. Everything turns into a massive party when he is around,' the bride said. Sue said nothing was going to get in the way of their honeymoon - not even the start of Grimsby Town FC's season.Nick will miss the start of the season and the derby match with Lincoln City at Blundell Park on August 18 at 1pm.'Nothing is going to get in the way of the honeymoon. He is not crossing that line,' said Sue.    Football-mad Nick was almost instantly on the phone to wedding planners to rearrange the times of their wedding and reception when England got through to the quartersShe added: 'We are big football fans and Nick never misses a Grimsby Town game.'Football has ruled my life for years. Window cleaner, Nick runs his son Sam's under 16 football squad Sussex Elite Windows.The happy couple will be joined by daughter Ellie Stevenson, 24 and Libby Hawley, 13.Nick said: 'As soon as England won I was straight on to the wedding planner. But it is not as easy as you think. The photographer is into football too so was happy to accommodate us.'They were all very thoughtful and moved the wedding at The Courtyard forward and the reception at Greens of Gretna to 5.30pm.'We are massive England fans.'            Katrina and Samuel Williams were married at a ceremony attended by their parents in Cyprus last month. Their plans for a reception in the UK have been hit by the England match She added: 'We can't get hold of everyone that's due to come so I've had to drive about telling people the news.'I've found the whole thing traumatising - we have a toddler to look after and I work full time as a nurse and just don't need this extra stress.'The couple believe the venue's change of plans is due to the England match. But the bar insists it never offered the large function room that Katrina and Samuel, 31, say they requested.          They believe the decision not to give them the room they wanted is due to the England gameA spokesman said: 'It was unfortunate that on this occasion, communication between ourselves and the party involved was delayed and details were not finalised until just over a week before the event. We would like to make it clear that this was not a failure on our part.'Due to this delay, the apparent mix-up over the function room offered only came to light very late in the day.'We have done our utmost to find an alternative solution and it is a shame that we have not been able to do so.'England's quarter final tie, which kicks off at 3pm, has caused headaches for scores of couples planning their big days.            Humber Dock Bar and Grill in Hull insists the dispute is the result of an administrative mix-upOne couple, from Norwich, have arranged for the game to be screened at their wedding.Hayley Cullum, 31, and her fiancée, James Adams, 33, will wed at 2pm today - and have their photos taken at the same time as kick off.  'I'm not bothered by it but all of the men on both sides love football, especially Adam's mates who cry over it, so I thought instead of losing half of my wedding party I would put a TV up' she told the Eastern Daily Press. Ahead of the game, one senior Church of England cleric has warned people not to watch the game on mobile phones or tablets if they are in church.One couple have installed a satellite dish so their guests can watch the quarter-final - but they will have to wait until after the speeches and watch the game 'as live' two hours later. Elsewhere gig-goers at the British Summer Time in Hyde Park didn't arrive until at least 5pm - three hours after it starts - because 'unpatriotic' organisers aren't showing the football and won't allow people to come and go from the site.And organisers of London's Pride festival are considering putting up giant screens so the tens of thousands taking part on Saturday afternoon can cheer England on rather than stay away.            Matt Yeo and fiancee Sophie Wood (pictured) are installing satellite dishes at their wedding reception but guests will have to wait until 5pm and watch the match 'as live' Graphic designer Matt Yeo told the Daily Telegraph: 'It has changed our plans quite dramatically. My fiancee Sophie is not a football fan and is very against the idea of having any football because you don't want to detract from the big day. 'But I felt that everyone will be looking at their phones or feeling like they wish they were watching it.'Matt and fiancee Sophie Wood, both 30, will instead set up a television for their guests to watch the match at 5pm, instead of having the speeches ruined by the distraction of the World Cup. Guests will be told to turn their phones off so they can watch the game later without knowing the result. Meanwhile groom-to-be Carl Gould, who finds himself in a similar position, told the Guardian he would not install screens as 'we're not getting married in a Wetherspoons'.    He said he hoped the wedding day would bring the England team luck, saying: 'If we could have a wedding win, and an England win – that would be ideal.' Bride-to-be Jodie Houlston, from Lincolnshire, said: 'OK England, you're starting to worry me now.'If you're kicking a ball around a bit of grass upstages me on my wedding day I may have to have the first a strop of my life.'        Wedding plans have been thrown into chaos because of the big game at 3pm on SaturdayDanni Jordan, of Ipswich, said her brother had posted a Facebook status asking his fiancée if they could move their wedding to Sunday, so he doesn't miss the match.   Ashleigh Marie said: 'When the England game will be playing during your wedding... woo, nothing like paying all that money to have missing guests.'  Groom-to-be Gary Snoad tweeted: 'My own wedding clashing with the big game on Saturday - what have I done? Apologies to the English contingent, definitely the Welsh family side that picked the date.' And Zoey Olivia, of Watford, added: 'Just realised I'm at a wedding on Saturday and England are playing... I'm so torn. I hope there's a TV.'Sandra Millar, the Church of England's head of 'life events', said: 'For those attending a wedding service at 3pm, I'd strongly encourage you to make sure you are fully on-side with the happy couple and switch off your mobile phone in advance.'Rev Millar added that while guests 'may be forgiven' for checking the score at the reception - doing this in church should be given the 'red card'.She told the Daily Telegraph: 'For those getting married on Saturday, like England fans you might experience a few nerves - but you can be sure that it will also be the best day of your life, with memories to cherish. 'Who knows, come 6pm, that may be something you share with the rest of the nation too'.  Though she is English, bride-to-be Carmel, 27, from the Midlands, says there would not be any options for fans to watch the game at her wedding to Killian, 30, in South Wales on Saturday.'We don't have the facilities to do so in the venue, so that's a good excuse.'No-one has directly asked for us to put it on but there have been several jokes and suggestions, if you know what I mean. People who would like to have it on but don't want to straight out ask or come across as rude or anything.'Asked how she would react if anyone sneaked off to catch a glimpse of the television, Carmel said: 'I'd probably be like, 'Are you serious?!''I don't mind people checking the scores or having a quick look on their phones while we're all milling about but if anyone goes off to the accommodation I won't be best pleased!'It's at 3 so it sits quite nicely between our ceremony and dinner. As long as they're around and engaging, I'm happy to have a little give and take,' she said.'I think all our friends and family are pretty respectful so I don't think they'd push it really.''There's been some heated debates'George Morey, 25, and the soon-to-be Aimee Morey, 24, have managed to secure a screen for their wedding reception at a golf club in Swanley, Kent, and say 'dinner will be pushed'.'There's certainly been some heated debates about the game but she's come round to the idea of it now,' said George, a Millwall fan who works as a trainee lift engineer.'If we win it will just add to the atmosphere of the day. We can't wait.'I've had this in my head that England will play this day since the draw in December.'He added: 'I was thinking it would be the Germans in the quarter-final but I'll take Sweden and a first semi-final in 28 years instead.'Couple who began romance aged 13 allow wedding guests to watch England match during vows | Great Yarmouth News - Great Yarmouth MercuryNorwich couple to screen World Cup game at wedding | Latest Norfolk and Suffolk News - Eastern Daily Press

title: Seal chases woman street
story: This is the hilarious moment a seal was spotted defending his owner's turf in the middle of an unsuspecting Australian suburb (pictured)  Video footage reveals a seal who sat in the centre of a home's front yard in Beachport, South Australia engaging in a stare-off with a female passerbySeal pups play tug of war with a sheet of plastic washed up...Give us a lift, mate! Ship picks up a hitchhiking seal that...Share this article    (stock image) New Zealand fur sealThey're the largest of all fur seals The sea mammals raise their body on their front flippers to move forwardFur seals can e to depths of up to 200m These seals are found in the islands of Bass Strait and parts of Tasmania, Victoria's south, islands of South Australia and southern New South Wales They eat bony fish, squid and octopus                         The seal and woman appeared to stare each other down before the seal played 'security guard.'The seal started to chase the woman down the street.The standoff between the woman and suspected Australian fur seal was sighted in the small  coastal town, 379km south-east of Adelaide.It comes after another seal was spotted in the upper-market Sydney suburb of Rush Cutter's bay in the city's east.A fur seal was sighted sunbathing in a park in the exclusive eastern suburb of Adelaide. A portion of the park was blocked off by council staff while the seal napped in front of the multi-million-dollar waterfront views.A City Of Sydney spokesperson at the time told the ABC barriers were set up as a precaution to protect the public as well as encourage the seal to move away from the site. Sydney Harbour fur seal blocked from returning to Rushcutters Bay Park - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
