story: NewsNew Aptamil baby milk formula is making babies sick claim parentsDanone insists its product has been tested and is safe to consume&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmma Gill10:28, 7 JUL 2018Updated14:32, 7 JUL 2018NewsSarah Foster with baby Tobi, who had a bad reaction to the new formula milk (Image: MEN Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFurious parents have hit out at a the makers of a popular formula milk, claiming its new recipe is making their babies sick. Aptamil has changed its First Infant milk powder in recent weeks, but parents have flooded the product's Facebook page with complaints. They say youngsters are being sick and suffering from diarrhoea after drinking the new milk, the Manchester Evening News reported. Some mums have shared photos of the feeds, saying the milk is curdling and the powder doesn't dissolve.  And they say Danone, which makes Aptamil and insists the new recipe is safe to drink, has given different explanations to concerned families. Sarah Foster said her eight-week-old son Tobi had been fine on the old milk since birth, but became ill after trying the new tub. She told the paper: He was sick straight away when feeding him the first feed of it. As soon as it hit his tummy it was back up. It was then I noticed it didn’t mix the same. I’ve since stockpiled the old formula but it will only last a week or two. We have no choice but to use the new one as everywhere has sold out or no longer stocks the old one.  Sarah, 35, also mum to seven-year-old Joshua, says the company is giving various responses to customers who have complained. She added: I’m so annoyed and upset about this as Aptamil are giving different answers to different people, from blaming how mums are making up the formula and then backtracking. I’ve got my replies from them through Facebook messenger and you can tell they're generic responses despite coming from a person. Parents have also complained the company has reduced the size of its packs from 900g to 800g while keeping the tubs at the same price.  Bel Garner shared a Facebook post about the new formula earlier this week and has since received more than 200 messages from people having similar issues. The experienced mum-of-three, said she was offended by the suggestion mums could be making the feeds up wrong and has criticised the new guidance to make the milk using water that's cooled for half an hour. She said: Aptamil please tell me what magical skill I have to tell my 4 1/2 old month baby that she has to wait 30 minutes for her bottle (more so if you have a baby that’s not in a routine or feeds on demand) as we are advised as parents NOT to pre-make bottles and to make each feed up as we need it and to cool down with cold water for immediate use.  Mum Susan Johnston, whose daughter was being very sick, refusing feeds and suffering with diarrhoea, posted a photo of one bottle made up with the old formula and one with the new to show the company the difference between the two. She said: The pictures I took were of Aptamil old and new formula. Why is there such a difference between the two when they were both made at same time in the same way? And another mum Amanda Higson, urged the company to take action over the number of complaints. She said: I don’t think it’s a coincidence a lot of babies are getting poorly on the new First Infant milk. Why change the formula when it was fine? I think this should be looked into as a priority, either bring the old milk back or look into why babies are reacting so badly to the new one. In the heat/weather at the moment it’s even more of a priority when babies are either not taking to the milk or being sick/upset tummy and losing fluids. Sort it Aptamil, very disappointing.

story: NewsNew list of hand luggage items set to be BANNED from flights leaving the UKGovernment plans could see make-up, baby powder, coffee and spices banned from hand luggage&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill17:28, 7 JUL 2018NewsPowders including cosmetics or coffee could be banned from hand luggage as part of a new rules being drawn up by the government (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEveryday items such as make-up, coffee and spices could be banned from hand luggage on all flights leaving the UK, claims a new report. The government is believed to be drawing up a new list of items that must be put in the hold. It comes after Australia, the US and New Zealand introduced similar bans last month. They adopted the new rules after Australian officials were rocked by a foiled plot to blow up an Ethiad flight from Sydney to Abu Dhabi last year. Islamic State sent the sophisticated device from Syria to a terror cell in Sydney hidden in a meat mincer.  A major terror attack may only have been averted when the suitcase was abandoned at check-in, possibly because it was too heavy.  The Times reports that the new rules could bring powders under the same restrictions as liquids.  All powders would be restricted to 12 ounces or 56 grams and would have to go through further security checks. The rule on liquids were introduced in the wake of 9/11. However, there are fears the new rules could mean even longer lines at airport security. It comes amid worries that the new UK passports, which are blue in colour, will increase queues at border control. The Department of Transport did not comment on The Times' report.

title: new ppi wave pension mis
story: NewsIs this the new PPI? Wave of pension mis-selling could spark windfall for thousandsDuped savers could each pocket £50,000 due to their underperforming pension schemes&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPippa Allen-Kinross11:52, 7 JUL 2018Updated13:52, 7 JUL 2018NewsSenior woman inserting coins into piggybank (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDuped savers could each pocket a &pound50,000 windfall due to their underperforming pension schemes as part of a mammoth SIPP scandal engulfing the UK - which industry experts fear will overtake the current wave of PPI claims. A colossal &pound10 billion worth of badly performing SIPPs - Self Invested Personal Pensions - are believed to have been mis-sold to hundreds of thousands of Brits by unscrupulous financial advisors. Now potential victims are being urged to check if they can reclaim huge portions of their lost cash and the government has set up a special &pound120 million fund to compensate losers so far. A maximum &pound50,000 compensation sum is currently available from the large fund managed by The Financial Service Compensation Scheme and the figure is set to rise by 75 per cent to a &pound85,000 maximum in the next nine months as claims grow. However industry figures such as pension expert Zoe Pearson warn that the true cost of mis-sold pensions is closer to &pound10 billion and will sweep the country like the current phenomenon of PPI claims that has gripped the nation over the past few years.  Read more: Taxed to death: The astonishing amount of income tax people pay decades after leaving work for the last time Miss Pearson, who heads the country’s all female team of claim specialists Pension Claim Consulting Ltd , told : “Thousands upon thousands of people are unaware they’ve been mis-sold SIPPS. Unless you know what to look for it’s difficult to know what a mis-sale is although quite often when people realise they’ve been mis-sold to, they’re too embarrassed to take action. “However, the financial services industry has firm rules, so any mis-sale should be pursued. “Even basic calculations give you an idea of the true scale of this scandal. Average compensation for mis-sales sit at around &pound25,000 for private pensions and &pound50,000 for final salary pensions so the total figure for the mis-sales of SIPPs is going to be around the &pound10bn mark. “In fact if this was brought to the forefront and the government advised people to check the status of their pensions that might even be an underestimation. The government needs to launch an investigation to unearth the true amount.” Labour MP Frank Field has hit out at the SIPP conmen and vowed to bring the industry into line whilst industry experts reveal the true figure of mis-selling is growing at an unprecedented rate and the true loss of mis-selling will run into billions as the number of victims rocket.  Shocking 30.4million Brits face disappointment when they finally get to stop working - the plan to fix it The Financial Ombudsman however are allowed to raise their compensation ceiling and can award up to a further maximum of &pound150,000 for many cases. The SIPP scams involved unscrupulous Financial Advisors preying on savers who were promised massive returns of up to 20 per cent a year only for their savings to be squandered on get rich quick schemes including investing in airport parking, holiday properties and green energy projects. The Financial Conduct Authority revealed one in eight savers think an advisor has mis-sold them a financial product such as a pension. The FCA advise people who think they have been mis-sold a pension to raise a complaint as soon as possible as there are time-limits in place which could affect the outcome of your claim. Their report called the Financial Lives Survey was widely praised by industry experts who believe that the government have underestimated the scale of mis-sold pensions such as SIPPs however the Commons Work and Pensions Committee have demanded tighter safeguards to protect savers. Committee Chairman Frank Field MP said: “I am concerned about the role of SIPPs as platforms that help funnel unwitting clients’ pension savings into dodgy and inappropriate investments. SIPPs are happy to skim off their fee on the way but there are serious questions about their commitment to due diligence and consumer protection. “When an unscrupulous financial advisor channels a victim’s money through a SIPP into an investment that then collapses, it is not enough for the SIPP provider to shrug their shoulders and say ‘caveat emptor’. “I will be writing to the FCA to ask what they are doing to ensure SIPPS are not acting as handmaidens to the pension-snatchers.”

story: NewsPippa Middleton reveals the one thing she's refusing to give up during her pregnancyPippa Middleton is expecting her first child with husband James Matthews&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer17:36, 6 JUL 2018NewsPippa is pregnant with her first child (Image: Rex)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen women find out they're pregnant, their lives change forever. Even though they're still months away from meeting their baby, the changes to their day-to-day life start immediately. There's a whole host of foods they can no longer eat, they can't drink and they will sometimes have to give up the hobbies they love. But there's one thing Pippa Middleton, who is expecting her first child with husband James Matthews, is refusing to give up despite that growing baby bump.   Writing in her column for Waitrose Weekend , the Duchess of Cambridge's little sister, 34, explains why she is still playing tennis.  She said: I've been a tennis fan since childhood, as player and spectator, and have been keen to continue playing safely throughout pregnancy. Take Serena Williams – she famously proved that women can play a high level of tennis from two months (when she won the 2017 Australian Open) up to eight months. Few of us can relate to this elite excellence, but if you're a healthy, well-trained player with an uncomplicated pregnancy there's no reason why you can't continue a good level of tennis.  It is believed Pippa is due in October. And it's not just playing which Pippa enjoys, and she's a regular at Wimbledon. She was in the crowds for day four of this year's competition with her brother James.

title: pride london 2018 thousands gather
story: NewsPride London 2018: 'One million' people gather in the sunshine in capital for annual LGBT+ paradeThe celebration of all things LGBT+ is marking it's 46th year in the capital and the estimated turnout is huge&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPippa Allen-KinrossElaine McCahill17:05, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn estimated one MILLION people are thronging the streets in London to take part in the annual Pride parade as the capital basks in hot weather. Pride raises awareness and support for the LGBT+ community , and is frequently celebrated as one of the most inclusive events in the world. The theme for London Pride 2018 - its 46th year - is #PrideMatters. There are 30,000 people and 472 organisations taking part in the annual parade itself, which is one of the world's biggest LGBT+ celebrations.  Countless spectators took to the streets along the parade route from Regeant Street to Picadilly Circus and Trafalgar Square.  The world famous parade will wind through London and include performances from Sophie Ellis-Bextor , George Shelly, Sue Rie, Sinitta, Alyssa Edwards and Courtney Act. There will also be a pop-up silent disco in Trafalgar Square, courtesy of Pride's official music partner Amazon Music, and a special celebration at John Lewis' Summer of Sound Rooftop. Pride in London has also launched a new app for this year's event which shows the updated schedule . The Mirror has changed its logo to a rainbow in honour of the celebration, with the slogan 'Proud to support Pride'.  Temperatures in London are expected to reach 31C today, and those attending the parade have been encouraged to take water and suncream with them. The parade was opened by mayor of London Sadiq Khan and women and equalities minister Penny Mourdant. It kicked off at 12pm from Portland Place, and will travel through Oxford Circus, Regent Street, Piccadilly Circus, Pall Mall and Trafalgar Square before finishing on Whitehall. Groups taking part in the parade include Mosaic LGBT Youth Centre, Educate and Celebrate, which aims to make schools LGBT-friendly places.  Groups from the NHS also took part in the parade to mark its 70th anniversary.  Pride director Christopher Joell-Deshields said this year's parade was the most diverse to date.   He said: “It's just a day to be proud of really - people are able to just come and be who they are and celebrate whatever they want. Trafalgar Square Stage performances began at 11.50am, with an introduction by host Michael Twaits at 11.45am. The Women’s Stage in Leicester Square and the Cabaret Stage on Dean Street kicked off at 12.30pm. The Golden Square Family Stage in Golden Square will begin at 1pm. People will be able to take part in activities in the Community Village in Soho Square from 12pm It's recommended that people avoid busy locations like Trafalgar Square and Piccadilly Circus. The parade comes to an end at 5pm after which Sophie Ellis-Bextor and Alexandra Burke will entertain crowds in Trafalgar Square.   London's Met Police issued an open letter asking people to remain vigilant during the celebartions. “Pride is renowned internationally for being one of the safest and friendliest events in London, and this year we are working as hard as ever to prepare,” said Commander David Musker. There was some controversy surrounding the event as some criticised the decision to allow only 30,000 people participate in the parade.  A further 20,000 applied to take part but London Pride said it wasn't 'practical' to allow everyone to take part as the parade would then take around nine hours.  Veteran LGBT campaigner Peter Tatchell said limiting numbers felt like discrimination.  It has been reported that more than 100 groups had their applications denied when they were lodged after the cut-off date.  “The limit on the size of Pride feels like anti-LGBT+ discrimination,” Mr Tatchell said.

title: primark investigates after hair bobble
story: NewsPrimark investigates after hair bobble dyes little girl's hair bright GREENThe four-year-old from North Wales was wearing the £1 hair tie as she played in a paddling pool&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKelly WilliamsPippa Allen-Kinross11:07, 7 JUL 2018Updated11:52, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A little girl's light blonde hair has been dyed bright green by a hair bobble from Primark she was wearing while splashing in a paddling pool .  Four-year-old Celyn Jones' hair has been washed every day since it went green on Monday, but the colour still remains.  Her parents Stephen and Lowri Jones from Llangefni in Anglesey, North Wales , are warning others to be careful about using the &pound1 hair ties from the fashion store, which is now investigating what happened.  The couple say they have tried everything to remove the dye, and although the colour is fading it is still clearly visible in little Celyn's bright blonde hair.  Strangely, the hair bobble in question was not even green, but dark coloured.  Lowri told the Daily Post : On Monday, I put Celyn's swimming costume on her after smothering her in sun cream.  I tied her hair up with one of the bobbles we'd bought from Primark to keep her hair out of her face. About 20 minutes later, I started to notice her hair was turning green. I took the bobble out and the green dye just spread throughout her hair. I didn't think much about it at first, thinking the water in the paddling pool would wash it out, but it didn't. The mum-of-five said she has tried all kinds of different shampoos and even resorted to using Fairy Liquid on her daughter's hair. The 33-year-old added: Celyn's hair is very light so you can see there's still quite a lot of green in it. Her hair does look a mess and she's having to go to school like that. I've explained to the teachers but Celyn is loving it.

story: NewsSisters' shocking WhatsApp messages while mum lay dying in faeces-strewn bed crawling with maggotsCatherine Purcell died after daughter's "extreme neglect" in Kirkby, Liverpool&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNeil DockingMark Chandler17:12, 7 JUL 2018Updated18:21, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman shared shocking messages with her sister as their dying mum lay in a faeces-strewn bed that was crawling with maggots.  Catherine Purcell, 68, died while being eaten alive and lying in a “cesspit of her own faeces and bodily fluid” at the home she shared with her daughter in Kirkby, Liverpool .  This week, her husband John Purcell, 72, and 35-year-old daughter Catherine Purcell junior, 35, were given suspended jail sentences for neglecting the disabled great-grandmother.  Prosecutors said the great-grandmother's bed was so soiled it had been chemically destroyed by her own bodily fluids, the Liverpool Echo reported.   David McLachlan, QC, prosecuting, said this reaction burned the skeletal victim’s skin and her infected body was then fed on by maggots. He argued during that the pair knew she was dying, but failed to seek medical aid, which three weeks beforehand would have saved her life. During the harrowing trial into the death of Mrs Purcell, Mr McLachlan read out messages exchanged between Purcell junior and her sister Kellie, who had not visited the house for six months and was not charged with any offences. One message read: Ye girl co dad said fore to just ignore her for a bit and let her do with put cuppa tea and biffs let’s see if she’ll give in that way but every time one of us walk in she gets worse surly she can smell it in her f***ing hands when she smoking Oh I jus don’t know what to do coz she can’t walk so I can’t even get her to the bath room to giv her a bath and no matter what way we look at her were gona end up with this all over use as well even if she could walk she’s gonna have us plasted in s*** as well she’s just not assed to say the least girl either she isn’t a bit bothered that she’s like that she licks off if we tell he to at least wash her hands to eat her tea etc. She f***ing flipped on dad av few times now coz she’s had to get wash she like pig lying in her Own s*** descusting I feel like f***ing dragging her by the head and f***ing throwing her in the f***ing bath tats how bad she is girl.  In one text, Kellie Purcell asked: Have u sorted little room yet girl I got bedding for single and double here just finishing sorting curtain now sweat p***ing out of me like tap carnt breath &amp I stink. He accepted her bedroom was “disgraceful”, but said he didn’t know it was that filthy until she died, because the bed was covered by a duvet.

title: town shuts shopping streets today
story: NewsTown shuts shopping streets today for "public safety" during England World Cup match fearing 'intimidating' celebrationsCouncillors in Ashby, Leicestershire, have denied being World Cup "killjoys"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlan Thompson09:46, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A town centre will close its shopping streets during the England World Cup match over fears wild fan celebrations will intimidate people.  England will take on Sweden at 3pm today in a crucial quarter-final clash, but shops and two streets in Ashby, Leicestershire, will be shut down for the duration.  The controversial move comes after police were called in when large numbers of chanting England supporters marched down a street on Tuesday night after Gareth Southgate's side beat Colombia on penalties.    Video showed some people clambering on top of a lorry amid rowdy scenes in the town, LeicestershireLive reported.  And Leicestershire County Council says Market Street and Brook Street in the town centre will now be closed between 2pm and 6.30pm today for public safety. It is not thought that any damage was caused during Tuesday's high-spirited celebrations, but businesses are not taking any chances. Ashby town councillor and business owner John Coxon said that celebrations around the games could sometimes be intimidating. He said: I think some of the business owners are fearful of what might happen. Our neighbours have said they’re going to close early rather than risk any aggravation. People like to celebrate and it’s understandable, but for some it can be a bit intimidating. Like most market towns, businesses in Ashby can’t afford to lose 25 per cent of their trade on a Saturday.

title: uk weather scorching britain hot
story: NewsUK weather: Britain boils during 33C heatwave as sweltering commuters strip-off on hottest day, roads melt and Wimbledon fans sizzleTemperatures remain above average for the 12th day in the row as the country is in the midst of its longest heatwave since 1976 - and it's set to get hotter tomorrow&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline ReporterRachel Bishop17:41, 6 JUL 2018Updated23:14, 6 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCommuters were left sweltering in packed-out trains and tubes and roads have started metling as the sweltering 33C heatwave continues. Today is expected to top the previous hottest day record of 32C - and temperatures are going to stay high this weekend as England take on Sweden in the World Cup. Tourists and workers in London suffered through boiling conditions as they travelled home tonight as they faced temperatures of up to 35C on packed tube carriages. A signal failure at White City in west London brought chaos to the central line - with one station announcer saying he wasn't sure if the train would be waiting at the station for five minutes, five hours, or five years.  The central line consistently breaks records with temperatures peaking at 35.5C last summer - this exceeds the EU limit of 30C at which it is legal to transport cows, sheep and pigs. Trains from Paddington were also delayed due to an electricity failure and trains from Liverpool Street disrupted thanks to a points failure - causing thousands of people to wait in stations in the unberable hear. As the heatwave has raged on for nearly two weeks passengers travelling through Essex said people have fainted on trains as they travel home in 28C to 30C heat.  Some have hit out at rail firms by comparing the conditions on packed trains to a sauna with no air conditioning and barely any room to move. As the temperatures remain above average for the 12th day in the row Wimbledon fans were seen struggling as they watched on day five of the championships. Fans were seen fanning themselves and trying to cover their skin to avoid getting burnt as they tried to focus on the game. And this morning 'official pigeon scarer' Rufus the Hawk had to begin his daily shift at 5am on Centre Court to avoid the heat. Yesterday a West Berkshire Council bin lorry got stuck in Newbury yesterday after the road melted beneath it.  Thames Valley Police said the street had to be closed overnight to enable the damage to be assessed causing travel chaos through the town centre. Drivers have also been warned about driving in extreme temperatures over fears driving in the intense heat is almost like driving with a blood-alcohol reading. SEAT have published new information on driving in extreme temperatures, warning that people who make mistakes with their air conditioning during the intense heatwave risk lowering their driving ability.    A koi carp called 'Big White Fish' has even been rushed to hospital this week after getting burnt in the ongoing hot weather. Owner Pat Smythe, 70, from Burton-on-Trent noticed a big patch of red scales on his back and rushed him to the vet. Pet owners have been urged to take measures to stop their animals getting sunburn - with dogs , rabbits, cats, cows and even goldfish at risk - as the country is in the midst of its longest heatwave since 1976. Derby vet Paul Revell said: Believe it or not, fish can get sunburnt if they spend too long at the surface of a pond or lake.  There could be some relief from the heat for a brief period this weekend as some scattered showers will develop over Britain but most areas will remain dry and warm. An amber level heatwave alert has been issued for western parts of England with temperatures soaring over the next few days. London and the South East will bear the brunt of the sweltering conditions and high pressure will dominate the weather with prolonged periods of sunshine and more scorching air from the continent blocking any periods of cooler, unsettled Atlantic conditions. This has created an area of clear air above the UK, where cloud is suppressed and winds have been low to allow maximum heat to come through from the sun.  Hot conditions are expected to continue into next week. It may be sporadically cloudy and slightly fresher in the northwest at times with a little more rain or drizzle . However, for those wanting a respite from the heat, there is some hope on the horizon. More unsettled weather may start to develop later this month with occasional spells of more changeable conditions edging across the UK, particularly in the north and northwest.

story: NewsPranksters raid Ikea ahead of England vs Sweden World Cup match - and place some very cheeky signsAt first glance, the signs could pass for Swedish - but look a little closer&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor13:34, 7 JUL 2018News (Image: Bloomberg)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Unless you've been living under a rock for the last three weeks (in which case, lucky old you) you'll have noticed the UK is in the grip of World Cup fever.  Three words in particular are doing the rounds all over social media, 22 years since David Baddiel and Frank Skinner teamed up with the Lightning Seeds and first sang them.  Maybe you're sick of the Three Lions' It's coming home refrain and never want to hear it ever again.   Or maybe you love the beautiful game so much, you'd go into Ikea ahead of the England vs Sweden match and place some very cheeky signs about the shop.  This is what a group of imaginative pranksters from a local radio station have done ahead in their local Ikea ahead of today's quarter final game in Samara.  At first glance (and to a non Swedish speaker), the signs look perfectly legitimate.   But once you spell it out, it's those three words again...  'Football Etsk&oumlmm&aringnhj&oumlme' See what they did there?  The signs in question were put up in Gateshead IKEA. Not only that, but they've all been priced at &pound19.66, which, as we all know, is a reference to the last time England won the World Cup. The fake signs were placed on sofas, cookers, lights and tables in the store.  So what are England's chances against Sweden? We're currently the favourites to win with odds of 1/1.
